chapters.summary: This chapter explores the fundamental duality of mental states and their consequences. It emphasizes how our thoughts shape our reality and determine our happiness or suffering.

verses.translation: Mind precedes all mental states. Mind is their chief; they are all mind-wrought. If with an impure mind a person speaks or acts, suffering follows him like the wheel that follows the foot of the ox.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the law of Kamma. 'Dhammā' here refers to the mental aggregates. 'Paduṭṭhena' refers to a mind corrupted by the three roots of evil: greed, hatred, and delusion. The simile of the wheel and the ox signifies that just as the wheel is bound to the ox’s path, suffering is bound to the person who acts with a defiled intention.

story.title: The Story of Cakkhupāla Thera
story.content: Thera Cakkhupāla was a monk who became blind during his meditation practice. Despite his blindness, he attained Arahatship. One night, while pacing in meditation, he accidentally stepped on some insects. Visiting monks accused him of killing, but the Buddha declared him innocent as he had no intention to kill. To explain his blindness, the Buddha recounted a past life where Cakkhupāla was a physician. He had successfully cured a woman of blindness, but when she tried to cheat him out of his fee by claiming her eyes were getting worse, he felt slighted. In a fit of vengeful 'paduṭṭha' (malice), he gave her a different ointment that permanently blinded her. Because he acted with that evil mind, the retributive kamma followed him through many lives, resulting in his blindness in his final life. Even though he attained the highest spiritual fruit, the physical consequence of his past evil deed remained inescapable, illustrating how suffering pursues the evil-doer as the cart-wheel follows the hoof of the draught ox. The story emphasizes that mental purity is the only defense against future suffering, and that past actions, once committed with a corrupted mind, leave an indelible trail that eventually catches up with the doer.

verses.translation: Mind precedes all mental states. Mind is their chief; they are all mind-wrought. If with a pure mind a person speaks or acts, happiness follows him like his never-departing shadow.
verses.commentary: The counterpart to Verse 1. 'Pasannena' refers to a mind clear of defilements, specifically faith and wisdom. Happiness (sukha) here is compared to a shadow—effortless, constant, and inherently tied to the source of the good action. It suggests that a virtuous person does not need to 'seek' happiness; it simply exists as a result of their mental state.

story.title: The Story of Maṭṭhakuṇḍalī
story.content: Maṭṭhakuṇḍalī was the son of a wealthy but extremely miserly Brahmin named Adinnapubbaka. When the boy fell deathly ill, his father refused to spend money on doctors, moving his son to the balcony so he wouldn't see his treasures. The Buddha, perceiving the boy's end, appeared before him. Maṭṭhakuṇḍalī, too weak to move, could only mentally profess his faith in the Buddha with a 'pasannena' (joyful and clear) mind. Following his death, he was reborn in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven. His father mourned at the grave until the boy appeared in a celestial form to reveal that his mental devotion alone had led to his rebirth in glory. The Buddha later confirmed to the grieving father that it is not the size of the gift, but the purity of the mind that determines kamma. By simply focusing his final consciousness on the Buddha's compassion, Maṭṭhakuṇḍalī ensured that happiness would follow him as surely as a shadow. This narrative illustrates that the mind's orientation toward the wholesome, even in the absence of physical ability to perform grand acts, creates a trajectory toward bliss. It serves as a profound comfort for those who believe they have little to offer externally, highlighting that the internal state is the ultimate architect of destiny.

verses.pali:
Akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me;
Ye ca taṃ upanayhanti, veraṃ tesaṃ na sammati.
verses.translation: ‘He abused me, he struck me, he defeated me, he robbed me’—in those who harbor such thoughts, hatred is not appeased.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses the psychology of resentment. 'Upanayhanti' means to bind or wrap up. When we repeatedly 'wrap' ourselves in past wrongs, we keep the fire of hatred (vera) alive. The Buddha points out that the real perpetrator is not the one who hit you in the past, but the one who hits you in your memory in the present.

story.title: The Story of Thera Tissa
story.content: Thera Tissa was the Buddha's cousin who entered the Order in his old age. Because of his royal background, he was arrogant and expected special treatment. When younger monks did not pay him the respect he felt he deserved, he would fly into a rage, shouting, 'He abused me, he insulted me!' He would then run to the Buddha to complain. The Buddha realized that Tissa was trapped in a cycle of resentment, constantly replaying his perceived slights. The Buddha explained that as long as he held onto these thoughts, his 'vera' (enmity) would never cease. The story highlights that Tissa's unhappiness didn't come from the actions of others, but from his own 'upanayhana'—his habit of nursing grievances. The Buddha taught that a mind that stores insults is like a room full of trash; it eventually begins to rot and smell. By harboring the memory of abuse, Tissa was essentially continuing the abuse himself. Only by letting go of the internal narrative of victimhood could he find the peace of the holy life. This teaching was not just for monks but for all who struggle with holding grudges, showing that the resolution of conflict starts with a mental ceasefire where one refuses to recount the details of past injuries.

verses.pali:
Akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me;
Ye ca taṃ na upanayhanti, veraṃ tesūpasammati.
verses.translation: ‘He abused me, he struck me, he defeated me, he robbed me’—in those who do not harbor such thoughts, hatred is appeased.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 3. It emphasizes that 'non-clinging' (na upanayhanti) to the memory of an injury is the only path to peace. It is an act of mental hygiene that stops the proliferation of hatred.

story.title: The Story of the Reconciliation of Tissa
story.content: Continuing from the story of Thera Tissa, the Buddha showed him that his younger colleagues were not his enemies, but fellow travelers. When Tissa finally stopped reciting his list of 'he struck me, he robbed me,' his anger naturally subsided. The Buddha taught that the cessation of hatred is an internal process. By refusing to give mental space to past injuries, the 'fuel' for the fire of anger is removed. The monks eventually reconciled, demonstrating that when even one party in a conflict stops harboring the thought of being wronged, the enmity ('vera') loses its power to persist. This story serves as a template for conflict resolution in Buddhism: it does not require the other person to change or apologize first; it requires the practitioner to stop the mental repetition of the injury. When Tissa surrendered his status and his grudges, he found that the 'hatred' he felt was actually a burden he had been carrying. The relief he felt was the 'upasammati'—the calming down—that occurs when a mind is finally free from the heavy weight of resentment. This internal peace then radiates outward, making social reconciliation possible and creating a harmonious environment for spiritual growth.

verses.pali:
Na hi verena verāni, sammantīdha kudācanaṃ;
Averena ca sammanti, esa dhammo sanantano.
verses.translation: Hatred is never appeased by hatred in this world. By non-hatred alone is hatred appeased. This is a law eternal.
verses.commentary: This is one of the most famous verses in the Pali Canon. 'Sanantano dhammo' refers to a timeless, universal law. 'Averena' is often translated as 'non-hatred,' which includes love (metta) and compassion (karuna). It suggests that matching hate with hate only adds fuel to the fire.

story.title: The Story of Kāḷayakkhinī
story.content: A householder’s wife, who was barren, brought a second wife into the house so her husband could have an heir. However, whenever the second wife became pregnant, the first wife, out of jealousy, caused her to miscarry by slipping medicine into her food. Eventually, the second wife died in childbirth, but not before vowing revenge. In their next lives, they were reborn as a hen and a cat; the cat ate the hen's eggs. Then they were a doe and a leopardess; the leopardess ate the doe’s fawns. Finally, one was reborn as a woman and the other as an ogress (Kāḷayakkhinī). The ogress chased the woman and her baby to the monastery where the Buddha was teaching. The Buddha called both of them forward and revealed their long history of mutual slaughter. He told them, 'If you continue this, your hatred will never end.' He taught them that responding to hatred with hatred is like trying to wash off blood with more blood. Through his teaching of 'non-hatred' (averena), the ogress was moved to compassion and the woman to forgiveness. They stopped their ancient feud right then and there. This story illustrates that without a conscious decision to choose 'non-hatred,' the cycle of vengeance can span eons, leading only to a legacy of grief and suffering for all involved. It proves that the 'eternal law' is the only escape from the labyrinth of Samsara's endless conflicts.

verses.pali:
Pare ca na vijānanti, mayamettha yamāmase;
Ye ca tattha vijānanti, tato sammanti medhagā.
verses.translation: There are those who do not realize that one day we all must die. But those who do realize this settle their quarrels.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the 'recollection of death' (maranasati) as a tool for peace. 'Yamāmase' implies 'going to the presence of Yama (Death).' The Buddha argues that most people fight because they act as if they are immortal. The 'wise' (medhagā) realize that since life is short, there is no time for the luxury of a quarrel.

story.title: The Story of the Kosambi Monks
story.content: In the city of Kosambi, a minor dispute over a water vessel escalated into a massive schism that divided the entire Sangha. The monks were so engrossed in their legalistic arguments that they ignored the Buddha's pleas for peace. Even when the Buddha warned them of the dangers of discord, they remained stubborn. Finally, the Buddha told them that their behavior stemmed from a lack of awareness of their own mortality. He noted that if they truly realized they were on the verge of death at every moment, they wouldn't waste their precious time on such petty bickering. When the Buddha eventually left them to spend the rains retreat alone in the forest, the laypeople of Kosambi stopped providing the monks with food in protest. Facing starvation and the cold reality of their situation, the monks finally reflected on the Buddha's words. They realized the folly of their pride and the waste of their spiritual potential. Understanding that death was the ultimate equalizer, they put aside their differences and reconciled. This story shows that the awareness of death (maranasati) is not a morbid thought, but a clarifying one. It strips away the ego's attachments and highlights the absurdity of holding onto quarrels. By acknowledging their shared destination—the grave—the monks found the common ground needed to restore harmony to their community and return to the path of practice.

verses.translation: Just as a storm throws down a weak tree, so does Mara overpower the man who lives for the pursuit of pleasures, who is uncontrolled in his senses, immoderate in eating, indolent, and dissipated.
verses.commentary: This verse defines the profile of spiritual vulnerability. 'Subhānupassiṃ' means focusing only on the 'attractive' or 'beautiful' aspects of things, leading to lust. 'Mara' here represents the defilements that lead to spiritual downfall. The 'weak tree' is one without the deep roots of mindfulness and restraint.

story.title: The Story of Culla Kāla and Mahā Kāla
story.content: Two brothers, Mahā Kāla and Culla Kāla, became monks. Mahā Kāla was diligent and focused on the 'unattractive' nature of the body (asubha) to overcome lust, while Culla Kāla remained attached to his former life as a householder. One day, their former wives invited them for alms to try and lure them back. Culla Kāla had no sense-restraint; he looked at the beautiful decorations and the fine food with a 'subhānupassiṃ' (pleasure-seeking) mind. His wives easily convinced him to disrobe by playing on his lack of discipline. However, when they tried the same with Mahā Kāla, he remained unmoved. Because he had trained his senses and practiced moderation, he was like a rock. The Buddha explained that Culla Kāla was like a weak tree—because he focused on pleasure, lacked sense-restraint, and was lazy in his practice, he was easily toppled by the 'storm' of worldly temptation. The story illustrates that spiritual failure is often a result of 'thin roots'—a failure to guard the doors of the senses. Culla Kāla’s downfall wasn't due to the wickedness of his wives, but his own lack of internal fortification. By contrast, those who cultivate energy and moderation create a 'root system' that can withstand even the most enticing lures of the world, proving that true strength lies in the quiet practice of daily restraint rather than grand gestures.

verses.translation: Just as a storm cannot prevail against a rocky mountain, so Mara can never overpower the man who lives meditating on the impurities, who is controlled in his senses, moderate in eating, and filled with faith and earnest effort.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 7. 'Asubhānupassiṃ' is the meditation on the 32 parts of the body to counteract lust. The 'rocky mountain' represents the stability of a mind established in 'saddha' (faith) and 'vīriya' (energy). This person is immune to the external and internal storms of Mara.

story.title: The Story of the Diligent Mahā Kāla
story.content: Continuing the story of the two brothers, Mahā Kāla faced his former wives with a mind like a mountain. Even when they surrounded him and tried to force him into household clothes, he maintained his mindfulness of the 'unattractive' nature of things (asubha). He realized that the physical beauty they displayed was temporary and prone to decay. Because he was 'moderate in eating' and 'restrained in senses,' his mind was not clouded by the dullness or agitation that affects the weak. He eventually rose into the air using his psychic powers and returned to the monastery, leaving his confused former wives behind. The Buddha praised him, saying that Mahā Kāla could not be moved by Mara because his practice was solid. He was like a 'rocky mountain'—no matter how hard the wind of sensual desire blew, it could not even make him flinch. This story highlights that the 'impurities' (asubha) meditation is not about hating the body, but about seeing it realistically to prevent the 'storm' of lust from taking hold. It teaches that the combined strength of faith, effort, and sensory discipline creates an impregnable fortress. Mahā Kāla’s victory was won long before he met his wives, through the thousands of small choices he made in the forest to remain diligent and restrained, proving that a 'mountain-like' mind is built one stone of mindfulness at a time.

verses.pali:
Anikkasāvo kāsāvaṃ, yo vatthaṃ paridahissati;
Apeto damasaccena, na so kāsāvamarahati.
verses.translation: Whoever, being depraved, devoid of self-control and truthfulness, should don the monk's yellow robe, he surely is not worthy of the robe.
verses.commentary: This verse criticizes the focus on external symbols over internal reality. 'Kāsāvaṃ' (the yellow robe) is a symbol of the 'Arhats' (the pure ones). 'Anikkasāvo' means 'not free from the stains (kasāva) of defilements.' The Buddha suggests that wearing the robe without 'dama' (restraint) and 'sacca' (truth) is a form of spiritual fraud.

story.title: The Story of Devadatta’s Robe
story.content: Devadatta, the Buddha’s cousin, was driven by ambition rather than a desire for enlightenment. Once, while the Buddha was traveling, Devadatta put on a robe that had been offered specifically to a high-ranking monk, hoping to trick people into thinking he was an Arhat. He lacked both 'self-control' and 'truthfulness,' acting only for gain and fame. When the Buddha learned of this, he uttered this verse, explaining that the robe is not just cloth; it is a representation of the 'stainless' state of mind. Because Devadatta was still 'stained' by jealousy and greed, his act of donning the robe was a mockery. The Buddha noted that wearing the uniform of a saint does not make one a saint, just as wearing the clothes of a king doesn't make one a ruler. Devadatta’s lack of 'sacca' (integrity) made him 'unworthy' (na arahati) of the very symbol he coveted. This story serves as a warning against hypocrisy in spiritual life. It emphasizes that the 'robe' is a commitment to a standard of behavior, not a shortcut to social status. For Devadatta, the robe became a weight that eventually dragged him down to the lower realms, as his internal corruption eventually manifest in his attempts to kill the Buddha and divide the community. The verse reminds us that true worth is measured by the absence of inner 'stains' rather than the presence of outward ornaments.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vantakasāvassa, sīlesu susamāhito;
Upeto damasaccena, sa ve kāsāvamarahati.
verses.translation: But whoever is purged of depravity, well-established in virtues and filled with self-control and truthfulness, he indeed is worthy of the yellow robe.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 9. 'Vantakasāvassa' means 'one who has vomited (vanta) the stains.' This refers to an Arhat. This person is 'susamāhito' (well-established) in 'sīla' (morality). The robe is a fitting garment for them because their internal and external realities are in perfect alignment.

story.title: The Story of the Worthy Sāriputta
story.content: Venerable Sāriputta, the Buddha's chief disciple, was the perfect embodiment of this verse. Even though he was the most senior monk, he remained humble and was always the first to perform the lowliest duties in the monastery. Once, a group of monks who did not recognize him criticized him for his simple behavior. Sāriputta did not get angry or defensive; he simply listened with 'dama' (restraint) and 'sacca' (truth). When they later realized who he was, they were filled with shame. The Buddha used this occasion to explain that Sāriputta was 'worthy of the robe' because he had 'vomited' all traces of pride and ego. His 'sīla' (virtue) was not a performance; it was his nature. Unlike Devadatta, who used the robe to hide his stains, Sāriputta’s robe merely reflected the purity that was already within him. The Buddha emphasized that a true 'Brahmana' or monk is one whose internal discipline matches their external appearance. Sāriputta’s worthiness came from his absolute integrity—he never spoke a word he didn't live, and he never lived a moment without mindfulness. This story teaches that the 'yellow robe' is truly deserved only when the heart is purged of the 'stains' of self-interest. It sets a high standard for spiritual leadership, emphasizing that true authority comes from the visible manifestation of invisible virtues like humility and patience.

verses.pali:
Asāre sāramatino, sāre cāsāradassino;
Te sāraṃ nādhigacchanti, micchāsaṅkappagocarā.
verses.translation: Those who mistake the unessential to be essential and the essential to be unessential, dwelling in wrong thoughts, never arrive at the essential.
verses.commentary: This verse is about 'wrong view' (micchā diṭṭhi). 'Sāra' means 'essence' or 'core.' People often treat worldly gains (wealth, fame) as 'essential' and spiritual practice as 'unessential.' Because their 'saṅkappa' (intention/thought) is misdirected, they wander in a maze of triviality and never reach the truth.

story.title: The Story of the Two Friends and the Gold
story.content: Two friends were walking when they saw a pile of what looked like gold. One friend immediately grabbed it, thinking he had found 'essence' (sāra) in the form of wealth. The other friend, however, recognized it as a pile of glowing filth that only looked like gold in the twilight. The first friend spent his whole life guarding this 'treasure,' only to realize on his deathbed that it was worthless and had actually poisoned him. The Buddha used this analogy to explain that most people live their lives 'dwelling in wrong thoughts' (micchāsaṅkappagocarā). They treat their physical bodies and their reputations as 'essential,' ignoring the 'essential' work of purifying the mind. Because they value the 'unessential' (asāra), they are always disappointed when the world inevitably changes. They 'never arrive at the essential' because they are looking in the wrong direction. The story illustrates that our 'saṅkappa' or intention acts like a compass; if it is set toward the material, we will only find the material. The tragedy of the 'mistaken' person is not that they failed to get what they wanted, but that they succeeded in getting something that had no ultimate value. This verse encourages the practitioner to constantly re-evaluate what they consider 'important,' stripping away the superficial to find the core of the Dhamma.

verses.pali:
Sārañca sārato ñatvā, asārañca asārato;
Te sāraṃ adhigacchanti, sammāsaṅkappagocarā.
verses.translation: Those who know the essential to be essential and the unessential to be unessential, dwelling in right thoughts, do arrive at the essential.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 11. It highlights 'Right View' and 'Right Thought' (sammā saṅkappa). By correctly identifying the 'core' (sāra) as the path to Nibbana and the 'husk' (asāra) as worldly distractions, the practitioner moves directly toward the goal.

story.title: The Story of the Wise Monk Sāriputta
story.content: Before he was a monk, Sāriputta was a young man named Upatissa. He was a brilliant student of a famous teacher named Sañjaya, but he realized that his teacher’s philosophy was 'asāra'—unessential—because it did not lead to the end of suffering. While his fellow students were satisfied with the 'unessential' benefits of intellectual debate, Sāriputta went out to find the 'essential.' When he heard the Dhamma from Thera Assaji, he immediately recognized it as 'sāra.' He knew that the 'essential' was the realization of the Four Noble Truths. Because he 'dwelt in right thoughts' (sammāsaṅkappagocarā), he did not get distracted by the prestige of his former school or the arguments of his former teacher. He 'arrived at the essential' (attaining the first stage of enlightenment instantly) because his internal compass was accurately calibrated. This story shows that the difference between the 'fool' and the 'wise' is simply the ability to distinguish the 'husk' from the 'kernel.' While others were lost in the 'unessential' details of metaphysics, Sāriputta focused on the 'essential' reality of cause and effect. His journey illustrates that spiritual progress is not about learning 'more,' but about learning 'right'—focusing exclusively on the thoughts and practices that lead to liberation. It is the clarity of his 'saṅkappa' that allowed him to cut through the confusion of the age and find the core of the Buddha's teaching.

verses.pali:
Yathā agāraṃ ducchannaṃ, vuṭṭhī samativijjhati;
Evaṃ abhāvitaṃ cittaṃ, rāgo samativijjhati.
verses.translation: Just as rain breaks through an ill-thatched house, so passion penetrates an undeveloped mind.
verses.commentary: This verse uses a vivid domestic simile. An 'ill-thatched' (ducchannaṃ) house has holes in its roof. Similarly, an 'undeveloped' (abhāvitaṃ) mind—one lacking in mindfulness and concentration—has 'holes' through which 'rāgo' (passion/lust) can leak in and rot the structure.

story.title: The Story of the Lustful Monk Nanda
story.content: Nanda was the Buddha's half-brother. On the day of his wedding to the beautiful Janapadakalyāṇī, the Buddha led him to the monastery and ordained him. However, Nanda’s mind was 'undeveloped' (abhāvitaṃ); he spent all his time thinking about his beautiful bride. His mind was like an 'ill-thatched house'; even though he wore the monk's robes, the 'rain' of lust (rāgo) leaked through his thoughts and made him miserable. He told the other monks he wanted to disrobe. The Buddha used his psychic powers to show Nanda the celestial nymphs in heaven, who were far more beautiful than his bride. Nanda then practiced diligently just to get those nymphs as a reward. However, through the act of 'developing' (bhāvanā) his mind, he eventually realized the impermanence of all beauty—both earthly and celestial. The 'holes' in his mind were patched by wisdom. The story shows that lust is not something that happens 'to' us from the outside; it is something that 'penetrates' us because we haven't built a protective roof of mindfulness. Nanda’s initial failure was not a lack of effort, but a lack of 'thatch'—he had no internal defense system to keep his memories from overwhelming his present reality. Only by 'developing' his mind through meditation did he create an impregnable shelter that could withstand any emotional storm.

verses.pali:
Yathā agāraṃ suchannaṃ, vuṭṭhī na samativijjhati;
Evaṃ subhāvitaṃ cittaṃ, rāgo na samativijjhati.
verses.translation: Just as rain does not break through a well-thatched house, so passion never penetrates a well-developed mind.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 13. A 'subhāvitaṃ' (well-developed) mind is compared to a house with a perfect, thick roof of thatch. Mindfulness and concentration act as the sealant that prevents the 'rain' of defilements from entering and causing damage.

story.title: The Transformation of Nanda
story.content: After practicing under the Buddha's guidance, Nanda’s mind became 'well-developed' (subhāvitaṃ). He no longer looked at beauty with the desire for possession. His mind was now like a 'well-thatched house.' When the other monks joked with him about the celestial nymphs, he replied that he no longer had any interest in them. He had attained Arahatship. The Buddha praised him, noting that just as 'rain does not break through a well-roofed house,' the passion (rāgo) could no longer 'penetrate' Nanda’s mind. His internal state was now sealed by the 'thatch' of wisdom and the 'rafters' of concentration. This story highlights that the goal of meditation is to build a 'house' that is weather-proof against the world. Nanda did not have to 'kill' his desires; he simply had to 'roof' his mind so that desires had no place to land. His transformation from a grieving, lust-filled groom to a serene, liberated saint is the ultimate proof of the 'subhāvitaṃ' mind. It demonstrates that any mind, no matter how 'leaky' or 'undeveloped' it starts out, can be made impenetrable through the consistent application of the Dhamma's 'thatching' techniques—mindfulness, restraint, and clear comprehension.

verses.pali:
Idha socati pecca socati, pāpakārī ubhayattha socati;
So socati so vihaññati, disvā kammakiliṭṭhamattano.
verses.translation: The evil-doer grieves here and hereafter; he grieves in both the worlds. He laments and is afflicted, recollecting his own impure deeds.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the psychological torment of a 'dirty' conscience. 'Idha' (here) refers to this life, and 'pecca' (hereafter) to the next. The 'evil-doer' (pāpakārī) is 'vihaññati' (afflicted) not by external punishment, but by the 'vision' (disvā) of their own corrupted actions (kammakiliṭṭha).

story.title: The Story of Cunda the Pig-Butcher
story.content: Cunda was a pig-butcher who lived near the Jetavana monastery for fifty-five years. He was a 'pāpakārī'—an evil-doer—who never gave alms and spent his days slaughtering pigs in a particularly cruel manner. As he lay dying, he began to experience the 'hereafter' even while 'here.' He lost his mind and started grunting and crawling on all fours like a pig. For seven days, he suffered in agony, 'recollecting his own impure deeds' through a delirious reenactment of his cruelty. The neighbors could hear him grunting in pain, and when he finally died, he was reborn in a realm of great suffering. The Buddha explained that Cunda 'grieved in both worlds.' In this world, the 'stain' of his actions (kammakiliṭṭha) haunted his dying moments, and in the next, he faced the results of his kamma. This story is a vivid warning that our actions are not forgotten by our own minds. The 'grief' mentioned is the inescapable 'backlash' of a life lived without compassion. Cunda’s 'affliction' was self-generated; the very pigs he had slaughtered became the architects of his mental hell. It teaches that the 'hereafter' is not a remote place, but a continuation of the state of mind we cultivate in the 'here.' By living a life of cruelty, Cunda ensured that his final vision would be one of 'impurity,' leading to a natural and agonizing lamentation that spanned the bridge between life and death.

verses.pali:
Idha modati pecca modati, katapuñño ubhayattha modati;
So modati so pamodati, disvā kammavisuddhimattano.
verses.translation: The doer of good rejoices here and hereafter; he rejoices in both the worlds. He rejoices and exults, recollecting his own pure deeds.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 15. The 'doer of good' (katapuñño) experiences 'modati' (joy) because their conscience is clear. They 'exult' (pamodati) when they 'see' (disvā) the 'purity' of their actions (kammavisuddhi). This is the bliss of blamelessness.

story.title: The Story of Dhammika the Lay Disciple
story.content: Dhammika was a 'katapuñño'—a doer of good—who was famous for his generosity and his observance of the precepts. On his deathbed, he requested the monks to chant the Dhamma for him. As they chanted, celestial chariots from the six deva worlds arrived to take him to heaven. Dhammika saw these 'pure deeds' (kammavisuddhi) as the chariots and politely asked the devas to wait so he could finish listening to the monks. His children thought he was speaking in delirium, but Dhammika was actually 'rejoicing in both worlds.' He died with a joyful mind and was reborn in the Tusita heaven. The Buddha noted that Dhammika 'rejoiced and exulted' because his mind was filled with the memory of his kindness. This story illustrates that a life of virtue provides a 'safety net' at the time of death. While Cunda was haunted by grunts, Dhammika was welcomed by celestial music. His 'rejoicing' was the natural outcome of a 'blameless' heart. The 'kammavisuddhi' or purity of action acts as a light that guides the doer through the darkness of transition. Dhammika didn't have to 'fear' the hereafter because he had already built a 'heaven' within his own mind through decades of selfless service. His story encourages the lay person to cultivate merit 'here,' so they may 'exult' when they finally look back and see a trail of 'pure deeds' behind them.

verses.pali:
Idha tappati pecca tappati, pāpakārī ubhayattha tappati;
Pāpaṃ me katanti tappati, bhiyyo tappati duggatiṃ gato.
verses.translation: The evil-doer suffers here and hereafter; he suffers in both the worlds. The thought, ‘Evil have I done,’ torments him, and he suffers even more when gone to realms of woe.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the word 'tappati,' which means to 'burn' or 'be tormented.' It describes the 'fire' of guilt. The evil-doer is first 'burned' by the mental realization 'Pāpaṃ me kataṃ' (Evil have I done), and then 'burned' (bhiyyo tappati) in the 'duggati' (woeful state) of a bad rebirth.

story.title: The Story of Devadatta’s Torment
story.content: Devadatta, after attempting to kill the Buddha and causing a schism in the Sangha, was 'tormented' (tappati) in his final days. He fell ill and, realizing the gravity of his 'evil deeds' (pāpaṃ me kataṃ), he sought to go to the Buddha for forgiveness. However, before he could reach him, the earth opened up and he was swallowed into Avici Hell. The Buddha explained that Devadatta suffered in 'both worlds.' Even before his death, the mental 'fire' of his guilt was so great that he couldn't find rest. But once he was 'gone to realms of woe' (duggatiṃ gato), his suffering became 'bhiyyo'—even more intense. The story emphasizes that 'pāpa' (evil) is like a debt that earns interest. The mental 'burn' of guilt in this life is merely the 'smoke' indicating the 'fire' that follows in the next. Devadatta’s tragedy was not just his external failure, but his internal 'burning.' He was a 'pāpakārī' who had cultivated a mind of such intense negativity that he literally could not stand on the same ground as the 'Stainless One.' This story serves as a stark reminder that the 'thought' of one's evil is a tormentor that cannot be escaped by fleeing. It teaches that the only way to avoid the 'burn' of the hereafter is to stop producing the 'heat' of unwholesome actions 'here' and 'now.'

verses.pali:
Idha nandati pecca nandati, katapuñño ubhayattha nandati;
Puññaṃ me katanti nandati, bhiyyo nandati suggatiṃ gato.
verses.translation: The doer of good delights here and hereafter; he delights in both the worlds. The thought, ‘Good have I done,’ delights him, and he delights even more when gone to realms of bliss.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 17. 'Nandati' means to delight or rejoice. The doer of good is delighted by the thought 'Puññaṃ me kataṃ' (Good have I done). This delight is 'bhiyyo' (even greater) in 'suggati' (a happy state/heaven). Merit is described here as a source of perpetual joy.

story.title: The Story of Sumanādevi
story.content: Sumanādevi was the youngest daughter of Anāthapiṇḍika, the great benefactor. She was a 'katapuñño'—a doer of good—who was deeply devoted to the Dhamma. Even on her deathbed at a young age, she remained clear-headed and called her father 'younger brother' (since he was only a Sotapanna and she had attained the higher stage of Sakadagami). She died with the delightful thought, 'Good have I done.' Because of her merit, she was reborn in the Tusita heaven. The Buddha explained that she 'delights in both worlds.' The joy she felt while 'here' was a preparation for the even greater delight she found after being 'gone to realms of bliss' (suggatiṃ gato). Her story illustrates that 'puñña' (merit) is the only true wealth one carries across the bridge of death. Sumanādevi’s 'delight' was not a product of her family’s wealth, but of her own 'good deeds.' Her death was not a tragedy but a promotion. While others mourned, she 'delighted' in the purity of her own life. This verse encourages us to see 'good' not as a duty, but as a 'delight'—a source of mental happiness that never runs dry. It teaches that the 'hereafter' for a good person is simply a more 'delightful' version of the 'here.' By filling the mind with 'puñña,' one ensures that the final 'thought' of this life is one of triumph rather than regret.

verses.pali:
Bahumpi ce saṃhita bhāsamāno, na takkaro hoti naro pamatto;
Gopova gāvo gaṇayaṃ paresaṃ, na bhāgavā sāmaññassa hoti.
verses.translation: Much though he recites the sacred texts, but acts not accordingly, that heedless man is like a cowherd who only counts the cows of others—he does not partake of the blessings of the holy life.
verses.commentary: This verse is a warning to scholars. 'Saṃhita' refers to the scriptures. A 'pamatto' (heedless) man may know the texts by heart, but if he is not 'takkaro' (a doer of it), he is like a 'cowherd' (gopo) who counts someone else's cows but gets no milk. He does not share in the 'sāmaññassa'—the fruits of being a monk (the paths and fruits of enlightenment).

story.title: The Story of the Two Friends (The Scholar)
story.content: There were two friends who became monks. One became a master of the Tipitaka (the scholar) and taught five hundred disciples, while the other lived a simple life in the forest and attained Arahatship (the practitioner). The scholar looked down on his friend, thinking he was ignorant of the texts. He planned to embarrass him by asking difficult questions in front of the Buddha. The Buddha, knowing his intention, visited them and asked the scholar questions about the 'Paths and Fruits' of enlightenment. The scholar, despite his 'much recitation' (bahumpi bhāsamāno), could not answer because he had only studied the map but never walked the path. He was the 'cowherd counting others' cows.' He had the prestige of a teacher but none of the 'blessings' of the holy life. This story highlights that intellectual knowledge is 'asāra' (unessential) if it doesn't lead to 'takkaro'—acting accordingly. The scholar was 'heedless' because he mistook information for transformation. He 'counted the cows' of the Buddha's wisdom, but since he didn't practice, he had no 'milk' or 'butter' (enlightenment) of his own. The verse serves as a powerful reminder that in the spiritual life, the only thing that counts is what you 'are,' not what you 'know.' It warns against the 'vanity of the expert' who knows every verse but has not yet conquered a single defilement.

verses.translation: Little though he recites the sacred texts, but puts the Teaching into practice, forsaking lust, hatred, and delusion, with right knowledge and emancipated mind, clinging to nothing of this or any other world—he indeed partakes of the blessings of a holy life.
verses.commentary: The final verse of Chapter 1. It defines the 'true practitioner.' Even if they know 'little' (appampi) of the texts, if they are 'anudhammacārī' (living in accordance with Dhamma), they are the true 'bhāgavā' (partaker). The criteria for success are the abandonment of the three roots of evil—'rāga' (lust), 'dosa' (hatred), and 'moha' (delusion)—and the attainment of a 'suvimuttacitto' (well-liberated mind).

story.title: The Story of the Two Friends (The Practitioner)
story.content: Continuing from the previous story, when the Buddha asked the 'practitioner' (the forest monk) questions about the 'Paths and Fruits,' he was able to answer perfectly because he had experienced them directly. He spoke 'little' (appampi) of the sacred texts, but he was an 'anudhammacārī'—one who lived the Dhamma. He had 'forsaken lust, hatred, and delusion' through his forest practice. He possessed 'sammappajāno'—right knowledge—not from books, but from insight into his own mind. He was 'clinging to nothing' (anupādiyāno) of this world or the next. The Buddha praised him in front of the scholar and his students, declaring that he was the one who 'partook of the blessings of the holy life.' This story concludes the 'Pairs' chapter by showing that the goal of the Buddha's teaching is not scholarship, but freedom. The practitioner 'had the milk' because he owned the 'cows' of his own experience. His story is the ultimate encouragement for anyone who feels they cannot memorize the vast scriptures. It teaches that one verse, if practiced 'to the end of births' (jātikkhayaṃ patto), is worth more than a thousand verses held only in the head. The 'holy man' is defined by his 'emancipated mind' (suvimuttacitto), a state where the 'Pairs' of happiness and suffering, here and hereafter, are finally transcended in the peace of Nibbana.

chapters.summary: This chapter emphasizes the importance of heedfulness and diligence in spiritual practice.

verses.pali:
Appamādo amatapadaṃ,
pamādo maccuno padaṃ;
Appamattā na mīyanti,
ye pamattā yathā matā.
verses.translation: Being heedful leads towards the deathless; being heedless leads towards death. The diligent do not truly die, while the negligent live as if already dead.
verses.commentary: The Buddha states a basic law of the path: careful, continuous mindfulness opens the way to Nibbāna, while a life of carelessness keeps one bound to birth and death. 'Deathless' here does not mean an eternal ego, but the end of the cycle of birth and death through realizing Nibbāna. Even while still alive, the heedless are like the dead because they do not make use of their precious human life for wholesome growth.

story.title: Queen Sāmāvati’s Unshakable Heedfulness
story.content: Queen Sāmāvati and her attendants were devoted disciples of the Buddha, constantly practising loving-kindness and listening to Dhamma. The jealous Queen Magandiyā plotted against them and had the palace wing set on fire. Even while flames surrounded them, Sāmāvati urged her attendants not to hate anyone and to maintain mindfulness and loving-kindness. After their death, they were reborn in heavenly realms due to this heedful practice. The Buddha pointed to them as examples of how heedfulness leads beyond death.

verses.pali:
Etaṃ visesato ñatvā,
appamādamhi paṇḍitā;
Appamāde pamodanti,
ariyānaṃ gocare ratā.
verses.translation: Knowing clearly the special value of heedfulness, the wise delight in being diligent and rejoice in dwelling in the domain of the noble ones.
verses.commentary: Once a person really understands how powerful heedfulness is, they naturally come to love it. The 'domain of the noble ones' is the way of those who have realized stages of enlightenment, whose minds are guided by wisdom and compassion. To delight in heedfulness means to enjoy being careful, present, and responsible in all actions of body, speech, and mind.

story.title: The Wise Ones Who Loved the Practice
story.content: After hearing the Buddha praise heedfulness, a group of lay followers and monks decided to reorganize their lives around steady practice. They woke early, listened to Dhamma, meditated often, and guarded their speech and actions. Over time, some attained stream-entry and higher stages, tasting the noble path for themselves. The Buddha explained that it was exactly because they truly appreciated the benefit of heedfulness that they could enter the 'resort of the noble ones'.

verses.pali:
Te jhāyino sātatikā,
niccaṃ daḷhaparakkamā;
Phusanti dhīrā nibbānaṃ,
yogakkhemaṃ anuttaraṃ.
verses.translation: Those wise ones who meditate constantly, with steady and strong effort, realize Nibbāna, the unsurpassed peace and freedom from bondage.
verses.commentary: Heedfulness becomes concrete as regular meditation and continuous cultivation of wholesome qualities. 'Sātatikā' highlights continuity, and 'daḷhaparakkamā' emphasizes firm, unshakable energy. Such practitioners reach 'yogakkhema', complete security from the bonds of greed, hatred, and delusion.

story.title: Sāmāvati’s Attendants Reach Safety
story.content: The story of Queen Sāmāvati includes many of her ladies-in-waiting who practised meditation daily under her guidance. When the fire consumed their residence, many of them died with calm, concentrated minds suffused with loving-kindness. The Buddha explained that their continuous meditation and strong effort had brought them close to Nibbāna, and their rebirth was in blissful states rather than realms of suffering.

verses.pali:
Uṭṭhānavato satimato,
sucikammassa nisammakārino;
Saññatassa ca dhammajīvino,
appamattassa yaso'bhivaḍḍhati.
verses.translation: For one who is energetic and mindful, who acts purely and thoughtfully, who is self-restrained and lives by the Dhamma, fame and good reputation keep increasing.
verses.commentary: Heedfulness shows itself in very practical qualities: getting up and acting when needed, paying attention, doing clean and considered deeds, restraining the senses, and living according to Dhamma. Such a person is trusted and respected, so their honour naturally grows. The verse reminds us that spiritual qualities also have visible effects in our everyday relationships.

story.title: The Monk Whose Reputation Blossomed
story.content: A young monk was once lazy and careless, and lay supporters spoke poorly of him. After being admonished by the Buddha, he changed completely, becoming diligent, mindful, and considerate in all his duties. Over time, people noticed his transformation, and the same villagers who once criticised him began to praise him highly. The Buddha remarked that diligence and restraint naturally cause a person’s good name to flourish.

verses.pali:
Uṭṭhānenappamādena,
saññamena damena ca;
Dīpaṃ kayirātha medhāvī,
yaṃ ogho nābhikīrati.
verses.translation: Through energy and heedfulness, through restraint and self-control, the wise person builds an island that no flood can overwhelm.
verses.commentary: The 'flood' symbolizes the powerful currents of greed, aversion, and delusion, as well as the pressures of worldly life. By combining effort, heedfulness, ethical restraint, and inner discipline, one creates a stable refuge in the midst of these storms. This refuge is the noble path itself, which cannot be destroyed by changing conditions.

story.title: Building an Island in the Flood of Life
story.content: A householder complained to the Buddha that worldly responsibilities were like a flood constantly threatening to drown him. The Buddha urged him to keep precepts, be careful with the senses, and meditate daily, explaining that these qualities form an island. The man followed this advice, and later reported that although his outer situation had not changed much, his inner stability had grown immensely. The Buddha said that he had begun to build the very island this verse describes.

verses.pali:
Pamādaṃ anuyuñjanti,
bālā dummedhino janā;
Appamādañ ca medhāvī,
dhanaṃ seṭṭhaṃva rakkhati.
verses.translation: Foolish people, lacking wisdom, follow after heedlessness; but the wise guard heedfulness as their greatest treasure.
verses.commentary: The mind that does not see long-term consequences runs towards distraction, carelessness, and indulgence. The wise see that heedfulness brings safety and freedom, so they protect it like a valuable jewel. This verse invites us to treat mindfulness and care as something precious, not optional.

story.title: The Careless Youth and the Careful Elder
story.content: Two relatives inherited a sum of money. The younger spent it wildly on entertainments, thinking only of immediate pleasures, and soon fell into debt. The older guarded his share carefully, investing in honest work and charity. When the youth came to the Buddha in misery, the Buddha contrasted his conduct with that of his elder relative, explaining that the fool clings to heedlessness while the wise protect heedfulness as their true wealth.

verses.pali:
Mā pamādaṃ anuyuñjetha,
mā kāmaratisanthavaṃ;
Appamatto hi jhāyanto,
pappoti vipulaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.translation: Do not pursue heedlessness; do not cling to the pleasures of sense desire. One who is diligent and meditates attains vast happiness.
verses.commentary: Here the Buddha warns that heedlessness and sensual indulgence support each other. A mind obsessed with pleasure will not settle into meditation, and a meditative mind loses interest in coarse sense-gratification. The 'vast happiness' mentioned is not just worldly comfort, but the deep peace that arises from collectedness and insight.

story.title: A Monk Torn Between Pleasure and Practice
story.content: A monk who still longed for his former luxurious life was often absent from meditation, visiting lay families for fine food and entertainment. When he confessed his struggle, the Buddha recited this verse, pointing out that real joy lies in diligent meditation, not in brief flashes of sense pleasure. The monk, ashamed yet inspired, renewed his effort and eventually experienced the deeper happiness of concentration.

verses.pali:
Pamādaṃ appamādena,
yadā nudati paṇḍito;
Paññāpāsādaṃ āruyha,
asoko sokiniṃ pajaṃ,
Pabbataṭṭho va bhummaṭṭhe,
dhīro bāle avekkhati.
verses.translation: When a wise person drives out heedlessness with heedfulness and climbs the tower of wisdom, he looks down upon the sorrowing folk, like one standing on a mountain watching people on the plain.
verses.commentary: Heedfulness here is described as an inner turning point: the wise use it to dispel their former carelessness. From the 'tower of wisdom' they see clearly how beings suffer due to their own actions and confusion. This is not a view of superiority, but of compassionate understanding born from a higher vantage point.

story.title: From Drunkard to Wise Elder
story.content: A man once known as a habitual drunkard suddenly reformed after hearing a Dhamma talk on heedfulness. He gave up alcohol, kept precepts, and began to meditate. Years later, as a calm and respected elder, he watched younger villagers repeating the same mistakes he had made. He told them that his view was now like someone on a hill seeing the dangers in the valley below, echoing the image used by the Buddha in this verse.

verses.pali:
Appamatto pamattesu,
suttesu bahujāgaro;
Abalassaṃva sīghasso,
hitvā yāti sumedhaso.
verses.translation: Among the heedless, the heedful one is wide awake; while others sleep, he goes on swiftly, like a fast horse leaving a weak one behind.
verses.commentary: Heedfulness makes spiritual progress rapid compared to those lost in distraction and laziness. The simile of the strong, fast horse shows how a determined practitioner naturally outpaces others, not out of competition, but due to consistent effort. The 'sleep' here is the sleep of ignorance and unawareness.

story.title: The Swift Horse of Practice
story.content: In a monastery, most monks relaxed during the afternoon, chatting or sleeping, while one monk quietly used that time for meditation and study. Over the years, his understanding and composure became far deeper than that of his companions. When people wondered why he seemed so advanced, the Buddha explained that the heedful practitioner advances like a swift horse among tired ones, as stated in this verse.

verses.pali:
Appamādena Maghavā,
devānaṃ seṭṭhataṃ gato;
Appamādaṃ pasaṃsanti,
pamādo garahito sadā.
verses.translation: Through heedfulness, Maghavā (Sakka) attained the lordship of the gods. Heedfulness is praised, heedlessness is always blamed.
verses.commentary: Maghavā, later reborn as Sakka, the king of the devas, earned his position by patient, diligent good deeds over many lives. The verse reminds us that even high heavenly states depend on heedful conduct and are not random gifts. It also states a general principle: wise people everywhere praise diligence and criticize negligence.

story.title: How Sakka Became King of the Devas
story.content: In a past life, Sakka was a village youth named Magha who carefully observed virtue, performed many acts of service, and encouraged others to do good. He rebuilt roads, created resting places, and supported the needy with constant effort. At death he was reborn as Sakka, king of the devas, due to this accumulated merit. The Buddha cited his story as proof that heedful goodness brings great results, even in heavenly realms.

verses.pali:
Appamādarato bhikkhu,
pamāde bhayadassivā;
Saṃyojanaṃ aṇuṃ thūlaṃ,
ḍahaṃ aggīva gacchati.
verses.translation: The monk who delights in heedfulness and sees danger in heedlessness burns away all fetters, subtle and coarse, like a blazing fire.
verses.commentary: To 'delight in heedfulness' means that careful awareness has become natural and joyful, not forced. Seeing clearly how dangerous negligence is, the practitioner keeps away from it as from a cliff-edge. This continuous clarity gradually destroys all chains that bind the mind, from gross defilements to very refined attachments.

story.title: Burning the Bonds
story.content: A monk once confessed to the Buddha that he was still troubled by subtle pride and restlessness. The Buddha encouraged him to increase his mindfulness and to carefully avoid any lapse into carelessness. Taking this to heart, the monk became intensely attentive in all four postures. Over time, even his subtle defilements faded away. The Buddha compared his progress to a growing fire consuming fine and coarse fuel alike, as stated in this verse.

verses.pali:
Appamādarato bhikkhu,
pamāde bhayadassivā;
Abhabbo parihānāya,
nibbānasseva santike.
verses.translation: The monk who delights in heedfulness and sees danger in heedlessness cannot fall back; he stands close to Nibbāna.
verses.commentary: At this stage, heedfulness is so strong that regression is very unlikely. The practitioner’s faith, wisdom, and virtue are firmly grounded, making backsliding into gross unwholesomeness almost impossible. Such a person lives 'near Nibbāna', meaning that the mind has already been largely freed from defilements and is moving toward complete liberation.

story.title: Standing at the Threshold of Nibbāna
story.content: An elder monk, known for his continuous mindfulness, was asked by younger monks how he remained so stable. He replied that he constantly remembered the danger in even small lapses of carelessness. The Buddha confirmed that a monk like this, who truly delights in heedfulness, is not likely to decline spiritually and is very close to the final goal. This verse was spoken to highlight such practitioners.

chapters.summary: This chapter focuses on the nature of the mind and the importance of training it.

verses.pali:
Phandanaṃ capalaṃ cittaṃ,
durakkhaṃ dunnivārayaṃ;
Ujuṃ karoti medhāvī,
usukārova tejanaṃ.
verses.translation: The mind is restless, unsteady, hard to guard and hard to control. The wise straighten it, like a fletcher straightens an arrow shaft.
verses.commentary: As soon as we begin to meditate, we see how quickly the mind jumps from object to object. Because it is naturally restless and easily pulled away, training requires patience and repeated effort. The simile of the arrow-maker reminds us that careful, continuous shaping is needed to make the mind straight and reliable.

story.title: Kundalakesī Tames Her Mind
story.content: Kundalakesī was once a passionate woman driven by intense emotions, even to the point of attempted revenge and violence. After meeting the Buddha and hearing the Dhamma, she ordained and began to train her very turbulent mind. Through steady practice, what was once wild and unstable became calm and sharp like a well-made arrow. The Buddha used her example to illustrate how even a highly agitated mind can be straightened through wisdom.

verses.pali:
Vārijo va thale khitto,
okamokata ubbhato;
Pariphandatidaṃ cittaṃ,
Māradheyyaṃ pahātave.
verses.translation: Like a fish pulled from the water and thrown onto dry land, this mind writhes about, wishing to escape from Māra’s domain.
verses.commentary: When the mind is pulled away from its usual objects of craving, it twists and struggles, just as a fish out of water flaps about. Māra’s domain is the territory of greed, hatred, and delusion. The verse describes how unsettled the mind can feel when we try to free it from unwholesome habits, and encourages us to persist through this discomfort.

story.title: A Mind Dragged Out of Its Old Element
story.content: A monk who had been attached to storytelling and gossip decided to practise noble silence and meditation. For many days his mind felt tortured, constantly trying to drag him back into old conversations. He felt just like a fish out of water. The Buddha told him that this was simply the mind leaving Māra’s domain, and urged him not to give up. Eventually, the monk’s mind settled and tasted a new kind of freedom.

verses.pali:
Dunniggahassa lahuno,
yatthakāmanipātino;
Cittassa damatho sādhu,
cittaṃ dantaṃ sukhāvahaṃ.
verses.translation: The mind is hard to restrain, quick, and falls wherever it likes. It is truly good to tame such a mind; a well-tamed mind brings happiness.
verses.commentary: The untamed mind chases every impulse, which creates a life filled with regret and instability. Training—through mindfulness, ethical conduct, and wisdom—gradually tames it. A disciplined mind becomes a source of genuine happiness, independent of external conditions.

story.title: From Unruly to Peaceful
story.content: A novice complained that his thoughts wandered to food, family, and old pleasures whenever he tried to meditate. The elders advised him to keep returning to the meditation object with patience rather than despair. Over months, the wild energy of his mind softened and became cooperative. He later testified that nothing in his former life could compare to the happiness of having a tamed mind, as this verse declares.

verses.pali:
Sududdasaṃ sunipuṇaṃ,
yatthakāmanipātinaṃ;
Cittaṃ rakkhetha medhāvī,
cittaṃ guttaṃ sukhāvahaṃ.
verses.translation: Very hard to see and extremely subtle, the mind goes wherever it wishes. The wise should guard this mind; a well-guarded mind brings happiness.
verses.commentary: Because the mind is subtle and often hidden behind words and actions, it is easy to overlook what is really happening inside. Guarding the mind means keeping careful watch over intentions, feelings, and thoughts, especially at the moment they arise. When the mind is protected in this way, it becomes a safe place, bringing joy rather than trouble.

story.title: The Hidden Motive
story.content: A monk thought he was practising kindness, but deep down he craved praise and recognition. When a wise elder questioned him, he realized his subtle attachment and began to watch his intentions more closely. By guarding his mind at this deeper level, his practice became more sincere and peaceful. The Buddha taught this verse to show that guarding the mind, even in its refined movements, is the cause of real happiness.

verses.pali:
Dūraṅgamaṃ ekacaraṃ,
asarīraṃ guhāsayaṃ;
Ye cittaṃ saṃyamissanti,
mokkhanti Māra-bandhanā.
verses.translation: The mind travels far, wanders alone, is bodiless, and dwells in the cave (of the heart). Those who restrain this mind are freed from Māra’s bonds.
verses.commentary: The mind can leap instantly to distant places, past and future, and it does not depend on a physical form. Yet its usual 'cave' is this very body-and-mind combination. By learning to restrain and steady it, we slip free from the ropes of Māra—that is, from the forces that keep us bound to suffering.

story.title: The Monk With a Wandering Mind
story.content: One monk reported that though his body was in the monastery, his mind was constantly travelling back to his hometown, reliving memories. The Buddha explained that this is the nature of the mind, which can travel far even while the body sits still. He then encouraged the monk to gather the mind into the present through mindfulness of breathing. As the mind became more restrained, the monk felt less controlled by old habits, as if he had loosened Māra’s chains.

verses.pali:
Anavaṭṭhitacittassa,
saddhammaṃ avijānato;
Pariplavapasādassa,
paññā na paripūrati.
verses.translation: For one whose mind is not steady, who does not understand the true Dhamma, whose confidence wavers and is unstable, wisdom does not become complete.
verses.commentary: A mind that continually sways between doubt and distraction cannot develop deep insight. Understanding of the Dhamma must be accompanied by a certain inner stability and confident trust. Only when faith, clarity, and calm come together can wisdom fully mature.

story.title: The Doubting Monk
story.content: A monk kept changing teachers and meditation methods, never staying with one long enough to gain depth. His faith rose and fell depending on his mood. The Buddha pointed out that, like a plant constantly uprooted and replanted, his practice could not grow strong. This verse was spoken to show that an unsteady mind and wavering confidence obstruct the fullness of wisdom.

verses.pali:
Anavassutacittassa,
ananvāhatacetaso;
Puññapāpapahīnassa,
natthi jāgarato bhayaṃ.
verses.translation: For one whose mind is not soaked in defilements, whose awareness is not shaken, who has gone beyond both merit and demerit, there is no fear while awake.
verses.commentary: Here the Buddha describes an awakened person whose mind is no longer stained by greed, hatred, or delusion. Such a mind is not knocked around by pleasant and unpleasant experiences. Having transcended clinging even to good deeds and bad deeds, this person has nothing to fear: the usual grounds for anxiety and guilt have been removed.

story.title: The Fearless Arahant
story.content: Lay followers once asked an arahant monk if he feared death. He replied that his mind was no longer burdened by past unwholesome actions or anxious hopes for future rewards. Whether praised or blamed, alive or dying, he remained composed. The Buddha used such examples to show what it means to be 'fearless while awake' as described in this verse.

verses.pali:
Kumbhūpamaṃ kāyam imaṃ viditvā,
nagarūpamaṃ cittaṃ idaṃ ṭhapetvā;
Yodhetha Māraṃ paññāvudhena,
jitañ ca rakkhe anivesano siyā.
verses.translation: Seeing this body as fragile like a clay pot, and establishing this mind like a fortified city, one should fight Māra with the weapon of wisdom and then guard the victory, without clinging.
verses.commentary: The body is easily broken, vulnerable to sickness and death, while the mind can be made firm and defended like a city with strong walls. Wisdom is the weapon that cuts through Māra’s tricks—delusion, temptation, and fear. Even after gaining insight, one must protect the mind and avoid claiming victory as 'mine', otherwise new attachment appears.

story.title: Defending the City of the Mind
story.content: A group of monks on retreat became frightened when they heard strange sounds in the forest, imagining spirits and dangers. The Buddha reminded them that their real task was to strengthen the 'city' of the mind with mindfulness, and to use insight as their weapon against fear. When they reflected on impermanence and the fragility of the body, their panic faded. They continued practising, guarding their newfound courage without clinging to it.

verses.pali:
Aciraṃ vatayaṃ kāyo,
pathaviṃ adhisessati;
Chuddho apetaviññāṇo,
niratthaṃva kaliṅgaraṃ.
verses.translation: Soon, this body will lie upon the earth, cast aside, bereft of consciousness, like a useless log.
verses.commentary: The verse is a stark reminder of mortality and the impermanence of the body. Once consciousness separates from the body, it loses all the value we usually project onto it. Reflecting on this helps break attachment to physical form and pushes us to use our limited time wisely.

story.title: The Monk Who Feared Decay
story.content: A monk developed a strong attachment to his youthful, healthy body and was terrified of getting old. The Buddha instructed him to contemplate corpses and bodily decay in a charnel ground. Over time he saw clearly that his own body would inevitably become a lifeless mass like the ones before him. This reflection on impermanence, captured in this verse, helped him let go of vanity and fear.

verses.pali:
Diso disaṃ yaṃ taṃ kayirā,
verī vā pana verinaṃ;
Micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ,
pāpiyo naṃ tato kare.
verses.translation: Whatever an enemy may do to an enemy, or a hater to one they hate, a wrongly directed mind can harm a person even more than that.
verses.commentary: The greatest danger often comes not from outside, but from our own misguided thoughts and intentions. A mind directed towards hatred, cruelty, or delusion can lead us into actions that produce terrible results. This verse urges us to see our own mind as the first place to correct, rather than obsessing over external enemies.

story.title: The Man Who Was His Own Worst Enemy
story.content: A layman blamed his misfortunes on rivals he thought were plotting against him. In reality, it was his own anger and jealousy that caused him to speak harshly and ruin relationships. When he approached the Buddha, the Buddha explained that no outside enemy had harmed him as much as his own ill-directed mind. Realizing this, the man began to train his thoughts and speech, slowly transforming his life.

verses.pali:
Na taṃ mātā pitā kayirā,
aññe vāpi ca ñātakā;
Sammāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ,
seyyaso naṃ tato kare.
verses.translation: What neither mother nor father nor any other relative can do, a well-directed mind does for a person, and it does it even better.
verses.commentary: Loving relatives can support, protect, and guide us, but they cannot purify our mind for us. Only our own rightly directed mind—aimed at virtue, concentration, and wisdom—can lead us to true safety and liberation. This verse highlights personal responsibility: the most important 'help' in our life is how we train our own thoughts.

story.title: A Mother’s Love and a Mind’s Power
story.content: A devoted mother brought her wayward son to the Buddha, begging him to 'fix' the boy. The Buddha spoke gently, explaining that even a mother’s deep love has limits: she cannot walk the path on behalf of her child. He recited this verse, emphasizing that the son’s own mind, if rightly directed, could help him more than anyone else. Hearing this, the young man felt a sense of responsibility and later became a diligent practitioner.

chapters.summary: This chapter uses flowers as metaphors to illustrate the Dhamma, teaching about the nature of existence, the importance of virtue over empty words, and the cultivation of good deeds.

verses.pali:
Ko imaṁ paṭhaviṁ vicessati, yamalokaṁ ca imaṁ sadevakaṁ;
Ko dhammapadaṁ sudesitaṁ, kusalo puppham iva pacessati.
verses.translation: Who will investigate this earth and this realm of Yama with its devas? Who will examine the well-taught path of Dhamma, as a skilled person picks flowers?
verses.commentary: This verse asks who possesses the wisdom to comprehend the nature of existence across all realms. Just as a skilled florist carefully selects the best flowers, a wise person discriminates and chooses the teachings that lead to liberation.

story.title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks
story.content: Five hundred monks were discussing the nature of the earth and its extent. The Buddha, hearing their discussion, advised them not to be concerned with the external earth, but rather to investigate the earth element within their own bodies. This verse was spoken to encourage them to turn their attention inward to understand the true nature of phenomena.

verses.pali:
Sekho paṭhaviṁ vicessati, yamalokaṁ ca imaṁ sadevakaṁ;
Sekho dhammapadaṁ sudesitaṁ, kusalo puppham iva pacessati.
verses.translation: A disciple in training will investigate this earth and this realm of Yama with its devas. A disciple in training will examine the well-taught path of Dhamma, as a skilled person picks flowers.
verses.commentary: This verse answers the previous question. A Sekha (one in training, from stream-winner to Anāgāmī) has the wisdom and dedication to investigate the nature of existence thoroughly. Through practice and insight, they discriminate between what is beneficial and what is not, just as an expert chooses the best flowers.

story.title: Continuation of the Five Hundred Monks
story.content: The Buddha explained that it is the disciple in training (Sekha) who has begun walking the path who can truly investigate and understand the nature of existence. Unlike worldlings, such disciples have developed insight and can discern the Dhamma clearly.

verses.pali:
Pheṇūpamaṁ kāyam imaṁ viditvā, marīcidhammaṁ abhisambudhāno;
Chetvāna mārassa papupphakāni, adassanaṁ maccurājassa gacche.
verses.translation: Knowing this body to be like foam, comprehending its mirage-like nature, one should destroy the flower-tipped arrows of Māra and pass beyond the sight of the King of Death.
verses.commentary: This verse teaches about the insubstantial nature of the body. Like foam or a mirage, the body appears solid but is actually empty and transient. By understanding this, one cuts through sensual attractions (Māra's flowered arrows) and transcends death.

story.title: The Monk Who Contemplated Foam and Mirages
story.content: A monk, while traveling, saw bubbles of foam floating on water and a mirage shimmering in the distance. These sights inspired him to meditate on the impermanent and insubstantial nature of all phenomena, especially the body. The Buddha, reading his thoughts, appeared before him and spoke this verse to confirm his understanding.

verses.pali:
Pupphāni h'eva pacinantaṁ, byāsattamanasaṁ naraṁ;
Suttaṁ gāmaṁ mahogho va, maccu ādāya gacchati.
verses.translation: Death carries away a person whose mind is attached to gathering flowers (of sensual pleasures), like a great flood sweeps away a sleeping village.
verses.commentary: Just as a flood overwhelms a village whose inhabitants are asleep and unaware, death suddenly overtakes those absorbed in sensual pleasures. The 'flowers' represent worldly attractions that distract one from spiritual practice.

story.title: The Story of King Viḍūḍabha
story.content: King Viḍūḍabha massacred the Sakya clan in revenge. On his return journey, he camped with his army on a riverbed. During the night, an unexpected flash flood swept them all away to the sea. The Buddha remarked that people absorbed in worldly pursuits are overtaken by death just as suddenly and helplessly.

verses.pali:
Pupphāni h'eva pacinantaṁ, byāsattamanasaṁ naraṁ;
Atittaññeva kāmesu, antako kurute vasaṁ.
verses.translation: Death brings under its sway a person whose mind is attached to gathering flowers (of sensual pleasures) and who is insatiable in desires.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes that those who are never satisfied with sensual pleasures remain under death's power. Insatiable craving keeps one bound to the cycle of birth and death. Only by abandoning attachment can one escape Māra's domain.

story.title: The Story of Pāṭipūjikā Kumārī
story.content: A young woman named Pāṭipūjikā offered alms to monks in the morning. That very evening, she suddenly died. When the Buddha was informed, he explained that even while pursuing sensual pleasures, death can strike at any moment, especially when one is insatiable in desires.

verses.pali:
Yathā pi bhamaro pupphaṁ, vaṇṇagandhaṁ aheṭhayaṁ;
Paleti rasam ādāya, evaṁ gāme munī care.
verses.translation: Just as a bee takes nectar from a flower without harming its color or fragrance, so should a sage go about in a village.
verses.commentary: This verse teaches the proper attitude for monks on alms rounds. Like a bee that takes only what it needs without damaging the flower, monks should accept offerings gratefully without becoming a burden to donors. This reflects contentment, moderation, and respect.

story.title: The Story of the Miser Kosiya
story.content: The Venerable Mahā Moggallāna used his psychic powers to bring a miserly treasurer and his wife to the Buddha. After hearing the Dhamma, they gained faith. The Buddha praised Moggallāna's skillful means, noting that good monks should help people develop confidence in the Triple Gem without causing inconvenience, just as a bee benefits from flowers without harming them.

verses.pali:
Na paresaṁ vilomāni, na paresaṁ katākataṁ;
Attano va avekkheyya, katāni akatāni ca.
verses.translation: Not the faults of others, not what they have done or left undone, but one's own deeds done and undone should one regard.
verses.commentary: This verse advises against the tendency to criticize others while ignoring one's own faults. True spiritual progress comes from self-examination and self-correction. By focusing on our own actions, we develop the mindfulness and wisdom necessary for liberation.

story.title: The Story of the Ascetic Pāveyya
story.content: A naked ascetic prevented his female follower from listening to the Buddha's teaching due to jealousy. Later, when she sought the Buddha's advice about this, the Buddha spoke this verse, explaining that examining one's own actions is more important than finding fault with others.

verses.pali:
Yathā pi ruciraṁ pupphaṁ, vaṇṇavantaṁ agandhakaṁ;
Evaṁ subhāsitā vācā, aphalā hoti akubbato.
verses.translation: Like a beautiful flower with color but no fragrance, so are well-spoken words fruitless for one who does not practice them.
verses.commentary: External beauty without substance is hollow. Similarly, eloquent words about the Dhamma are meaningless if not put into practice. True value lies in embodying the teachings, not merely reciting them. This verse warns against the gap between knowledge and action.

story.title: The Story of Chattapāni the Lay Disciple
story.content: A man named Chattapāni could recite the entire Tipiṭaka but his conduct did not match his knowledge. The Buddha compared him to a beautiful but scentless flower. True understanding manifests in ethical behavior and mental purification, not just intellectual knowledge.

verses.pali:
Yathā pi ruciraṁ pupphaṁ, vaṇṇavantaṁ sagandhakaṁ;
Evaṁ subhāsitā vācā, saphalā hoti kubbato.
verses.translation: Like a beautiful flower with color and fragrance, so are well-spoken words fruitful for one who practices them.
verses.commentary: This verse completes the pair, showing the positive outcome of aligning words with practice. When knowledge is embodied in action, it becomes truly powerful and beneficial. The fragrance of virtue spreads naturally from one who lives according to the Dhamma.

story.title: Continuation of Chattapāni's Story
story.content: After hearing the Buddha's teaching, Chattapāni reformed his ways and began to practice what he preached. His conduct became as beautiful as his knowledge, and he became like a flower that is both beautiful and fragrant. His transformation inspired many others.

verses.pali:
Yathā pi puppharāsimhā, kayirā mālāguṇe bahū;
Evaṁ jātena maccena, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ bahuṁ.
verses.translation: Just as from a heap of flowers many garlands can be made, so by one born a mortal many good deeds should be done.
verses.commentary: Human life is precious and rare, like having many flowers available. Just as a skilled garland maker creates many beautiful garlands from abundant flowers, one should use the precious human life to create abundant merit through good deeds. Life should not be wasted.

story.title: The Story of Visākhā
story.content: Visākhā, a devoted female disciple, performed countless acts of generosity and kindness throughout her life. When she offered a monastery to the Sangha, the Buddha praised her and spoke this verse, encouraging all to use their human birth wisely by performing many wholesome deeds.

verses.pali:
Na pupphagandho paṭivātam eti, na candanaṁ tagaramallikā vā;
Satañca gandho paṭivātam eti, sabbā disā sappuriso pavāyati.
verses.translation: The fragrance of flowers does not go against the wind, nor sandalwood, tagara, or jasmine. But the fragrance of the virtuous goes against the wind; the good person pervades all directions.
verses.commentary: Physical fragrances are limited by wind direction, but the fragrance of virtue transcends such limitations. A person of good character influences others everywhere, regardless of circumstances. Virtue has a universal appeal that spreads naturally in all directions.

story.title: The Question of Venerable Ānanda
story.content: Venerable Ānanda asked the Buddha whether there was any fragrance that could go against the wind. The Buddha replied with this verse, explaining that only the fragrance of virtue can travel in all directions, unlike physical perfumes which depend on wind direction.

verses.pali:
Candanaṁ tagaraṁ vā pi, uppalaṁ atha vassikī;
Etesaṁ gandhajātānaṁ, sīlagandho anuttaro.
verses.translation: Among all fragrances - sandalwood, tagara, lotus, and jasmine - the fragrance of virtue is supreme.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes that among all types of fragrance, the fragrance of moral virtue is the highest. While worldly fragrances please the senses temporarily, the fragrance of good character brings lasting benefit and happiness to oneself and others.

story.title: Continuation of Ānanda's Question
story.content: The Buddha elaborated on his previous answer, listing various precious fragrances known in ancient India. He concluded that none of these worldly fragrances, however expensive or rare, can compare to the supreme fragrance of virtue and moral conduct.

verses.pali:
Appamatto ayaṁ gandho, yāyaṁ tagaracandanī;
Yo ca sīlavataṁ gandho, vāti devesu uttamo.
verses.translation: Faint is the fragrance of tagara and sandalwood, but the fragrance of the virtuous is supreme, wafting even among the gods.
verses.commentary: The Buddha contrasts worldly and spiritual fragrances. Even the finest natural perfumes are weak compared to the fragrance of virtue, which reaches even the heavenly realms. This teaches that spiritual qualities are infinitely more valuable than material possessions.

story.title: The Heavenly Fragrance
story.content: The devas (celestial beings) are attracted to and delight in the presence of virtuous human beings. When someone of great virtue practices meditation or performs generous acts, the devas gather around to rejoice. This verse describes how moral perfection transcends even the celestial realms.

verses.pali:
Tesaṁ sampannasīlānaṁ, appamādavihārinaṁ;
Sammadaññā vimuttānaṁ, māro maggaṁ na vindati.
verses.translation: Among those of perfect virtue, dwelling in heedfulness, liberated by perfect knowledge, Māra cannot find the path.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the security of Arahants. Those who have perfected virtue, live mindfully, and are liberated through wisdom are beyond Māra's reach. They have closed all doors to defilement and suffering. Māra (representing temptation and death) has no access to them.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Godhika
story.content: Venerable Godhika attempted to attain final liberation six times, each time falling back due to illness. On the seventh attempt, knowing that Māra would try to distract him again, he attained Arahantship just before passing away. Māra searched everywhere but could not find where the Venerable had been reborn, as he had attained Parinibbāna.

verses.pali:
Yathā saṅkāraḍhānasmiṁ, ujjhitasmiṁ mahāpathe;
Padumaṁ tattha jāyetha, sucigandhaṁ manoramaṁ.
verses.translation: Just as on a heap of rubbish thrown on the highway a lotus may grow, fragrant and pleasing,
verses.commentary: This verse begins a simile that continues in the next verse. A beautiful, fragrant lotus can grow even in a garbage heap. This represents the potential for purity and wisdom to arise even in unfavorable conditions. It introduces the idea that enlightenment is possible in any circumstance.

story.title: The Story of Gārahadinna
story.content: Gārahadinna was a rich man's son who became a monk. Despite coming from a wealthy background, he lived contentedly with simple requisites. Some monks wondered how he could be so happy with so little. The Buddha explained that Gārahadinna had developed inner wealth through virtue and contentment, like a lotus blooming in muddy water.

verses.pali:
Evaṁ saṅkārabhūtesu, andhabhūte puthujjane;
Atirocati paññāya, sammāsambuddhasāvako.
verses.translation: So among the blind, rubbish-like ordinary people, the disciple of the Fully Enlightened One shines with wisdom.
verses.commentary: This verse completes the lotus simile. Just as a lotus stands out in a garbage heap, a wise disciple of the Buddha shines among ignorant worldlings. The 'blind' refers to those without spiritual insight. The Buddha's disciples possess the light of wisdom that illuminates the path beyond suffering.

story.title: Continuation of Gārahadinna's Story
story.content: The Buddha explained that Gārahadinna, though living among those attached to sensual pleasures, remained unaffected by worldly temptations. His wisdom and virtue made him stand out like a pure lotus flower, bringing inspiration to all who encountered him.
