Veyyagghapañcamaṃ hantvā, anīgho yāti brāhmaṇo.
verses.translation: Having killed mother (craving), father (conceit), two religious kings (eternalism and nihilism), and the dangerous hindrance as the fifth (doubt), the brāhmaṇa (Arahant) goes free from suffering.
verses.commentary: This verse is nearly identical to 294 but with a key difference in the final metaphor. While verse 294 speaks of destroying 'the kingdom with its officials,' this verse mentions destroying 'veyagghapañcama'—the dangerous or perilous obstacle that is the fifth, referring specifically to doubt (vicikicchā). Doubt is particularly dangerous because it prevents one from making spiritual progress, causing hesitation about the Buddha, Dhamma, Sangha, or the practice itself. An Arahant has completely eradicated this doubt along with all other defilements.

story.title: Venerable Bhaddiya's Complete Liberation (continued)
story.content: Continuing his explanation to the visiting monks, the Buddha elaborated further on the spiritual attainments of Venerable Bhaddiya. Beyond the basic defilements mentioned in the previous verse, the Buddha emphasized that Bhaddiya had also completely destroyed vicikicchā (doubt), which is like a dangerous tiger or perilous path that can trap practitioners. Doubt was particularly significant because it is one of the first three fetters that must be broken to attain Stream-entry. In the case of an Arahant like Bhaddiya, not only doubt but all ten fetters had been completely eradicated. The Buddha explained that despite his small physical stature, Bhaddiya was a spiritual giant who had accomplished what most beings fail to achieve across countless lifetimes. His complete freedom from all mental defilements meant he experienced no suffering, no anxiety, no fear—only perfect peace and liberation. This teaching helped the monks understand that spiritual attainment has nothing to do with physical appearance or worldly status, but everything to do with inner purification and the elimination of defilements.

verses.pali:
Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti, sadā gotamasāvakā;
Yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca, niccaṃ buddhagatā sati.
verses.translation: Fully alert and ever vigilant are Gotama Buddha's disciples who, day and night, constantly practice recollection of the Buddha.
verses.commentary: This verse begins a series of six verses (296-301) describing practitioners who maintain constant recollection or mindfulness of various objects. Buddhānussati (recollection of the Buddha) involves contemplating the Buddha's qualities: the Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Fully Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, the Well-Gone, Knower of Worlds, Incomparable Trainer, Teacher of gods and humans, the Awakened, the Blessed. This practice generates faith, joy, and inspiration while weakening defilements. Those who maintain this practice constantly remain 'fully awakened'—alert, mindful, and protected from unwholesome states.

story.title: The Woodcutter's Son Protected by Ogres
story.content: A woodcutter's young son regularly practiced recollection of the Buddha, constantly reflecting on the Buddha's qualities and virtues. One night, while his parents were away, he stayed alone in their forest dwelling. Two ogres approached, intending to frighten and harm the boy. When one ogre pulled the boy's leg, he immediately cried out 'Namo Buddhassa!' (Homage to the Buddha). Hearing these words of reverence, the ogres were deeply affected. Instead of harming him, they felt compelled to protect him. One ogre stayed as guardian while the other flew to King Bimbisara's palace, stole the royal food tray, and brought it back. The ogres fed the boy as if he were their own child. At the palace, the ogre left a message visible only to the king, explaining what had happened. In the morning, discovering the missing tray and reading the message, the king went to the forest. He found the boy safe and unharmed, praised his practice of Buddha-recollection, and learned how this mindfulness had protected him from danger.

verses.pali:
Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti, sadā gotamasāvakā;
Yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca, niccaṃ dhammagatā sati.
verses.translation: Fully alert and ever vigilant are Gotama Buddha's disciples who, day and night, constantly practice recollection of the Dhamma.
verses.commentary: Dhammānussati (recollection of the Dhamma) involves contemplating the qualities of the Buddha's teaching: well-proclaimed, visible here and now, timeless, inviting investigation, leading onward, to be experienced individually by the wise. This practice deepens understanding, generates appreciation for the teachings, and motivates continued practice. Regular reflection on the Dhamma keeps practitioners aligned with the path and protects them from wrong views and harmful influences.

story.title: The Woodcutter's Family (continued)
story.content: Impressed by how recollection of the Buddha had protected the woodcutter's son, King Bimbisara asked the Buddha whether mindfulness of the Buddha was the only protection against danger, or whether mindfulness of the Dhamma was equally powerful. The Buddha replied that there are six types of recollection that provide protection and lead to spiritual awakening. The second is recollection of the Dhamma. The Buddha explained to the boy's family that contemplating the Dhamma—its truth, its practical applicability, its immediate benefits, its invitation to personal investigation, and its ultimate goal of liberation—creates a powerful shield against harmful influences. Just as remembering the Buddha had protected the boy from the ogres, recollecting the Dhamma protects practitioners from wrong views, temptations, and unwholesome mental states. After hearing this teaching, the boy, his parents, and many others in the assembly attained Stream-entry (Sotāpanna), the first stage of enlightenment. Later, they all ordained as monks and nuns, eventually attaining full Arahatship through continued practice of these recollections.

verses.pali:
Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti, sadā gotamasāvakā;
Yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca, niccaṃ saṅghagatā sati.
verses.translation: Fully alert and ever vigilant are Gotama Buddha's disciples who, day and night, constantly practice recollection of the Sangha.
verses.commentary: Saṅghānussati (recollection of the Sangha) involves contemplating the virtues of the Buddha's noble disciples: practicing well, practicing straightforwardly, practicing methodically, practicing properly—the four pairs of persons (at the eight stages of enlightenment), worthy of offerings, hospitality, gifts, and reverential salutation, the unsurpassed field of merit for the world. This practice generates respect for the spiritual community, inspiration from their example, and appreciation for having access to enlightened guidance. It strengthens one's connection to the spiritual path.

story.title: The Woodcutter's Family (continued)
story.content: Continuing his teaching on protective recollections, the Buddha explained the third type: recollection of the Sangha—the community of enlightened disciples who have realized the fruits of the path. The Buddha described how contemplating the Sangha's virtues provides both inspiration and protection. The Sangha includes the four pairs of noble persons at eight levels of attainment: Stream-enterers and those on the path to Stream-entry, Once-returners and those on that path, Non-returners and those on that path, and Arahants and those on the path to Arahatship. These practitioners have directly realized the Dhamma and exemplify its fruits. By recollecting their noble qualities—their purity, dedication, wisdom, and freedom from defilements—one generates faith and determination to follow their example. This recollection protects the mind from doubt, strengthens commitment to the path, and creates beneficial connections with the spiritual community. The Buddha emphasized that all three recollections—of Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha—work together to keep practitioners fully awakened and protected on the path to liberation.

verses.pali:
Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti, sadā gotamasāvakā;
Yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca, niccaṃ kāyagatā sati.
verses.translation: Fully alert and ever vigilant are Gotama Buddha's disciples who, day and night, constantly practice mindfulness of the body.
verses.commentary: Kāyagatāsati (mindfulness directed to the body) is a comprehensive meditation practice involving contemplation of the body's true nature. This includes awareness of the thirty-two parts of the body, mindfulness of bodily postures and activities, contemplation of the body's elements, and reflection on its impermanence and impurity. This practice counteracts sensual attachment, generates dispassion toward the physical form, and develops clear understanding of the body's conditioned nature. It is considered one of the most effective practices for overcoming attachment and delusion.

story.title: The Woodcutter's Family (continued)
story.content: The Buddha continued teaching about protective practices, explaining the fourth recollection: mindfulness of the body. He described how practitioners should systematically contemplate the body's thirty-two constituent parts—from hair, nails, and teeth to internal organs, fluids, and tissues. This contemplation reveals the body's true nature: it is a composite of impermanent elements, subject to decay, and fundamentally impure despite superficial beauty. The Buddha explained that maintaining constant awareness of the body—whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down—develops profound insight. Practitioners begin to see through the illusion of a permanent, attractive self and recognize the body as merely a temporary assembly of elements. This understanding naturally reduces sensual craving and attachment. By practicing body contemplation day and night, disciples remain fully awakened to reality rather than being deluded by appearances. This mindfulness serves as both a meditation object for developing concentration and a foundation for insight into the three characteristics of existence: impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, and non-self. Combined with the three previous recollections, it provides comprehensive protection and leads toward liberation.

verses.pali:
Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti, sadā gotamasāvakā;
Yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca, ahiṃsāya rato mano.
verses.translation: Fully alert and ever vigilant are Gotama Buddha's disciples whose minds, day and night, delight in harmlessness (compassion).
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes the cultivation of ahiṃsā (non-harming) or compassion (karuṇā). A mind that delights in harmlessness naturally refrains from causing suffering to any living being through thought, word, or deed. This quality goes beyond mere avoidance of harm to active cultivation of compassion and kindness toward all beings. Such a mind is protected from anger, cruelty, and violence. Delighting in harmlessness means finding joy in the welfare and happiness of others, feeling distress at their suffering, and actively working to reduce suffering wherever possible.

story.title: The Woodcutter's Family (continued)
story.content: Continuing his comprehensive teaching, the Buddha explained the fifth protective practice: cultivating a mind that delights in harmlessness and compassion. He taught that practitioners should develop such deep compassion that their minds naturally take pleasure in non-violence and benefiting others. This goes far beyond simply avoiding obvious harm like killing or injuring. It means cultivating a mind so suffused with loving-kindness and compassion that even the thought of causing harm to any living being becomes impossible and repugnant. The Buddha explained that when disciples maintain this mental orientation day and night, their minds become like a fortress against anger, cruelty, and violence. They find genuine joy in others' welfare and feel natural concern when others suffer. This attitude protects them from accumulating negative karma through harmful intentions or actions. Moreover, a mind that delights in harmlessness radiates positive energy that affects others, creating harmony and peace in all relationships. The Buddha emphasized that this practice of compassion, combined with the previous four recollections, provides complete protection and keeps practitioners fully awakened on the path toward liberation.

verses.pali:
Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti, sadā gotamasāvakā;
Yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca, bhāvanāya rato mano.
verses.translation: Fully alert and ever vigilant are Gotama Buddha's disciples whose minds, day and night, delight in meditation.
verses.commentary: Bhāvanā (meditation or mental development) encompasses both samatha (tranquility) and vipassanā (insight) meditation. A mind that delights in meditation naturally turns toward inner development rather than external distractions. This practice includes all forms of formal meditation as well as continuous mindfulness in daily activities. Delighting in meditation means finding joy and fulfillment in the practice itself, not just in its results. Such practitioners naturally spend time in meditation, finding it more satisfying than sensual pleasures or worldly pursuits. This completes the set of six recollections that keep disciples fully awakened.

story.title: The Woodcutter's Family (conclusion)
story.content: Concluding his teaching on the six protective recollections, the Buddha explained the sixth practice: developing a mind that delights in meditation. He taught that practitioners should cultivate such love for meditation that their minds naturally incline toward it, finding joy and satisfaction in both tranquility and insight practices. The Buddha explained that when meditation becomes a source of delight rather than a duty, practice becomes effortless and sustainable. Disciples who truly enjoy meditation will naturally practice consistently, making rapid progress on the path. They find sitting in meditation more fulfilling than any worldly entertainment, and they maintain mindfulness throughout all daily activities. This final recollection ties together all previous practices, as meditation is the vehicle through which the Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha are realized, the body's nature is understood, and compassion is deepened. After receiving this complete teaching on the six recollections, the woodcutter's son, his parents, and many others in the assembly attained Stream-entry. Later they ordained and, through dedicated practice of these six recollections day and night, eventually attained full Arahatship, becoming living examples of the protective power of constant mindfulness.

verses.translation: Difficult is ordination, difficult to find happiness in it. Difficult is household life and full of suffering. Suffering is living with those of different views. The traveler (in saṃsāra) is continuously subject to suffering. Therefore, be not a traveler (in saṃsāra), be not one subjected to suffering again and again.
verses.commentary: This verse presents a realistic view of the difficulties inherent in both monastic and lay life, emphasizing that suffering is pervasive in saṃsāra (the cycle of rebirth). Ordination is difficult both to undertake and to maintain properly. Household life, though it may seem comfortable, is filled with responsibilities, anxieties, and attachments that cause suffering. Living with those who hold different views and values creates conflict and frustration. The ultimate message is that remaining in saṃsāra means continuous suffering. The solution is not to choose between these difficult paths, but to practice diligently to escape saṃsāra entirely through attaining Nibbāna.

story.title: The Suffering Monk Who Wanted to Disrobe
story.content: A certain monk found monastic life extremely difficult and was contemplating giving up his robes to return to lay life. He struggled with the discipline, found meditation arduous, and longed for the freedoms of household life. Before making his final decision, he went to the Buddha to inform him of his intention. The Buddha, perceiving his state of mind, asked him about his reasons for wanting to disrobe. The monk explained that he found monastic life too hard and believed lay life would be easier and more pleasant. The Buddha then taught him this verse, explaining the reality of both paths. He said that yes, ordination is indeed difficult, and finding true happiness in monastic life requires dedication. However, household life is also difficult and filled with its own forms of suffering—financial worries, family conflicts, social obligations, and emotional attachments. Moreover, whether monk or layperson, living with others who don't share one's values and views creates friction and unhappiness. The Buddha emphasized that the real problem wasn't choosing between monastic and lay life, but remaining in saṃsāra itself. As long as one continues in the cycle of rebirth, suffering is inevitable. The solution is to practice diligently wherever one is—whether as monk or layperson—to escape saṃsāra through attaining Nibbāna. Hearing this teaching, the monk understood that running from one form of life to another wouldn't solve the fundamental problem. He renewed his commitment to practice, eventually attaining Arahatship and permanent freedom from all suffering.

verses.pali:
Saddho sīlena sampanno, yasobhogasamappito;
Yaṃ yaṃ padesaṃ bhajati, tattha tattheva pūjito.
verses.translation: One who is endowed with faith and virtue, with fame and fortune, is honored wherever they go, in whatever place they visit.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the natural result of cultivating inner virtue combined with faith. Saddha (faith or confidence in the Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha) and sīla (moral virtue) are foundational qualities that naturally attract respect and recognition. When combined with good reputation (yasa) earned through virtuous conduct and with prosperity (bhoga) resulting from generosity and right livelihood, such a person is naturally honored wherever they travel. This isn't about seeking honor but recognizing that genuine virtue naturally commands respect. The verse particularly applies to faithful lay supporters who combine spiritual practice with ethical worldly success.

story.title: Citta the Householder's Pilgrimage
story.content: Citta was a devoted householder from Macchikasanda who had attained Anāgāmi (Non-returner), the third stage of enlightenment, after hearing Venerable Sāriputta teach. One day, Citta decided to visit the Buddha at Jetavana Monastery in Sāvatthi. He loaded five hundred carts with food and offerings for the Buddha and Sangha, and set out accompanied by three thousand followers. They traveled slowly, covering one yojana (about seven miles) per day, taking a full month to reach Sāvatthi. When they arrived, Citta went ahead with five hundred companions to pay respects to the Buddha. As he bowed before the Buddha, a miraculous shower of flowers descended from the sky, covering everyone present like rain. Throughout his month-long stay, Citta provided daily alms to the Buddha and the monks while also feeding his entire party of three thousand. Wherever Citta went—through villages, towns, and finally at Jetavana—people showed him tremendous respect. The Buddha taught this verse, explaining that Citta's honor came from his combination of deep faith in the Triple Gem, impeccable moral conduct, excellent reputation earned through virtuous living, and the fortune he used generously to support the Sangha. Such a person is naturally respected wherever they go.

verses.pali:
Dūre santo pakāsanti, himavanto'va pabbato;
Asantettha na dissanti, rattiṃ khittā yathā sarā.
verses.translation: The good shine from afar like the Himalaya mountains. The wicked, though near, are invisible like arrows shot in the night.
verses.commentary: This verse uses two powerful similes to contrast virtue and vice. Just as the snow-capped Himalaya mountains are visible from great distances, standing out clearly against the sky, truly good people are recognized even from afar. Their virtue, wisdom, and beneficial actions make them conspicuous and memorable. In contrast, wicked people, despite being physically present, remain invisible in terms of positive impact or lasting significance—like arrows shot into darkness that cannot be seen and leave no trace. The verse emphasizes that true goodness has visibility and impact, while wickedness, though it may seem powerful in the moment, ultimately has no lasting positive presence.

story.title: Marriage Between the Children of Ugga and Anāthapiṇḍika
story.content: Two householders, Ugga and Anāthapiṇḍika, arranged a marriage between their children to strengthen their friendship. However, Ugga's son, the bridegroom, had terrible character—he was cruel, addicted to alcohol, and morally corrupt. When he moved to Sāvatthi to live with his bride's family, his wickedness became apparent. He would beat servants, abuse his wife, steal from the household, come home drunk, and create constant chaos. Despite being physically present in Anāthapiṇḍika's home, his presence brought no value, only harm and embarrassment. Meanwhile, Anāthapiṇḍika's daughter, who had married into Ugga's family, was virtuous, kind, and devoted to the Buddha's teachings. Though far away in another city, her reputation for goodness traveled back to her father. People spoke admiringly of her gentle nature, her charitable works, and her devotion to the Dhamma. When Anāthapiṇḍika complained to the Buddha about his wicked son-in-law who brought only shame despite living in his house, the Buddha taught this verse, explaining how the truly good are visible and recognized even from far away, while the wicked, though nearby, remain spiritually invisible and leave no positive legacy.

verses.pali:
Ekāsanaṃ ekaseyyaṃ, eko caramatandito;
Eko damayam-attānaṃ, vanante ramito siyā.
verses.translation: Sitting alone, lying down alone, walking alone without laziness, alone taming oneself—such a one would find delight in living in the forest.
verses.commentary: This final verse of the chapter extols the value of solitary practice. The repetition of 'eka' (alone/solitary) emphasizes complete withdrawal from social engagement for the sake of intensive meditation practice. This doesn't mean permanent isolation but dedicated periods of solitary retreat where one can focus entirely on self-training (damayam-attānaṃ) without distractions. Forest dwelling (vanante) provides the ideal environment for such practice, away from the noise and stimulation of villages and cities. The verse suggests that one who practices thus, without laziness (atandito), will naturally find delight in solitude because it provides optimal conditions for spiritual development. This particularly applies to monks dedicated to intensive meditation practice.

story.title: Venerable Ekavihāriya (The Solitary Dweller)
story.content: A monk named Ekavihāriya Thera earned his name through his dedication to solitary practice. From the day of his ordination, he never spent even a single night in the company of other monks. He would always seek out isolated places—forest groves, mountain caves, or secluded spots far from human habitation—where he could practice meditation alone without any disturbance. Other monks found his extreme preference for solitude unusual and mentioned it to the Buddha. Some wondered whether he was antisocial or simply avoiding his duties to the Sangha. The Buddha called Ekavihāriya and asked him about his practice. The monk explained that he found solitude essential for his meditation, that being alone allowed him to focus completely on taming his mind without distractions. The Buddha praised him highly, saying that solitary practice in forests was indeed excellent for serious meditators. The Buddha taught this verse, explaining that those who sit alone, sleep alone, walk alone without laziness, and dedicatedly work on self-mastery will naturally find joy and fulfillment in forest solitude. Such practitioners, the Buddha said, make rapid progress because they are free from the numerous distractions and social obligations that come with community living. Ekavihāriya continued his solitary practice and eventually attained Arahatship, validating the Buddha's teaching about the value of dedicated solitary practice for liberation.

chapters.summary: This chapter describes the consequences of evil deeds that lead to states of woe, warning against lying, denial of wrongdoing, and immoral conduct.

verses.pali:
Abhūtavādī nirayaṁ upeti, yo vāpi katvā na karomi cāha;
Ubhopi te pecca samā bhavanti, nihīnakammā manujā parattha.
verses.translation: The liar who speaks untruth goes to hell, as does the one who, having done wrong, says 'I did not do it.' Both these people of base actions become equal after death, by taking rebirth in hell.
verses.commentary: This verse identifies two types of liars who face the same hellish destination. The first is 'abhūtavādī' - one who speaks what is untrue, fabricating lies. The second is one who commits an offense and then denies it with 'na karomi' (I did not do it). Though their methods differ - one creates falsehoods, the other conceals misdeeds - both engage in fundamental dishonesty. After death (pecca), they become equal (samā bhavanti) as 'nihīnakammā' - beings of base or low actions - in hell. The verse teaches that both active lying and defensive denial after wrongdoing lead to the same terrible result.

story.title: The Story of Sundarī the Wanderer
story.content: Sundarī was a beautiful female wandering ascetic who was hired by jealous rival teachers to destroy the Buddha's reputation. Following their scheme, she would walk toward Jetavana monastery in the evening and return the next morning, telling people she had spent the night with the Buddha. Most people didn't believe her accusations, recognizing them as lies motivated by jealousy. The plotters then escalated their scheme - they murdered Sundarī, buried her body near the monastery, and spread rumors that the Buddha's disciples had killed her to hide the Buddha's misconduct. They reported this to the king. When the body was discovered, an investigation revealed that the murderers themselves had hired Sundarī, killed her, and orchestrated the false accusation. The truth came out when the actual killers, drunk in a tavern, boasted about their deed and were overheard. They were arrested and confessed everything before being executed. Sundarī had committed the sin of abhūtavāda - speaking deliberate falsehood by falsely accusing an innocent person. The murderers added to their grave crime of killing by denying their deed, saying 'we did not do it' when questioned. When the Buddha heard this story, he spoke this verse, explaining that both Sundarī, who spoke untruth to slander the innocent, and the murderers, who committed evil and then denied it, would be reborn in hell. Though their specific actions differed, both engaged in fundamental dishonesty - one through active falsehood, the other through denial after wrongdoing - and both would face the same hellish consequences for their base actions.

verses.pali:
Kāsāvakaṇṭhā bahavo, pāpadhammā asaññatā;
Pāpā pāpehi kammehi, nirayaṁ te upapajjare.
verses.translation: There are many who wear the ochre robe but are of evil disposition and unrestrained. These wicked people, because of their evil deeds, are reborn in hell.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses a serious problem: monastics who wear the robes (kāsāva) but lack corresponding virtue. 'Kāsāvakaṇṭhā' literally means 'those with ochre-robe around their necks' - people who have taken on the external appearance of religious life. 'Pāpadhammā' means evil-natured, and 'asaññatā' means unrestrained or without self-discipline. Despite wearing the robes that symbolize renunciation and virtue, these individuals remain 'pāpā' (wicked) and will be reborn in hell due to their evil deeds. The verse warns that external symbols without internal transformation are worthless and even dangerous.

story.title: The Story of the Immoral Monks
story.content: In a certain region, a group of men ordained as monks not out of genuine spiritual aspiration but to escape poverty and gain an easy livelihood. They saw that monks received regular alms, comfortable lodging, and social respect without having to work. They wore the ochre robes and appeared outwardly as proper monastics, but their inner conduct was completely corrupt. These monks had no real discipline or moral restraint. They continued to engage in various forms of misconduct - they stole from lay supporters, lied shamelessly to get better offerings, engaged in sexual misconduct, drank alcohol secretly, and even committed violence. They would behave properly in public but indulged in all kinds of evil when they thought no one was watching. Their presence caused great harm to the Sangha's reputation. Sincere lay supporters who offered food and requisites to them were being deceived. These unworthy recipients were consuming offerings meant to support genuine practitioners, thereby depriving true monks and accumulating great negative karma both for accepting offerings they didn't deserve and for the misconduct they committed while wearing robes. When reports of these corrupt monks reached the Buddha, he was deeply concerned. He gathered the community and spoke this verse, warning that simply wearing the ochre robe - the symbol of renunciation and virtue - means nothing if one's conduct is evil and unrestrained. These men might appear to be monks externally, but internally they remained wicked people. Because they committed evil deeds while wearing the robes and accepting the offerings meant for the virtuous, their karmic burden was even heavier than if they had remained as laypeople. They would be reborn in hell due to their evil actions, and the robes they wore would provide no protection. The Buddha emphasized that what matters is not the external appearance but the actual purification of one's mind and conduct through proper practice of the Dhamma.

verses.pali:
Seyyo ayoguḷo bhutto, tatto aggisikhūpamo;
Yañce bhuñjeyya dussīlo, raṭṭhapiṇḍamasaññato.
verses.translation: It is better to swallow a red-hot iron ball, blazing like a flame, than to be an immoral and unrestrained person eating the alms food of the people.
verses.commentary: This verse presents a shocking comparison to emphasize the gravity of receiving offerings unworthily. For someone who is immoral (dussīla) and unrestrained (asaññata), eating the people's alms food (raṭṭhapiṇḍa) while not living virtuously is worse than swallowing a red-hot iron ball (ayoguḷa) that burns like fire. The Buddha uses this extreme image to convey that the karmic consequences of consuming offerings given in faith to the Sangha while living immorally are more terrible than even the most horrific physical torture. This hyperbole drives home the sacred trust placed in monastics.

story.title: The Warning to Unworthy Recipients
story.content: The Buddha spoke this verse as a direct follow-up to the previous teaching about monks who wore robes but lived wickedly. He wanted to make absolutely clear the karmic danger of accepting offerings while living immorally. The lay supporters who offered food to monks did so with faith and devotion. They believed they were supporting genuine practitioners who had renounced worldly life to pursue liberation. These donors often gave from limited means, sacrificing their own comfort to support the Sangha. When monks accepted these offerings while secretly living in violation of their precepts - engaging in theft, lies, sexual misconduct, intoxication, or other evils - they created immense negative karma. The Buddha explained with this startling verse that for such unworthy recipients, it would actually be better to swallow a red-hot iron ball blazing like fire than to eat the alms food offered by faithful supporters. Why such an extreme comparison? Because physical suffering, however intense, is temporary and limited to one lifetime. But the karmic consequences of deceiving donors, betraying their trust, and misusing offerings given in faith extend through countless lifetimes and result in rebirth in the hell realms where one experiences suffering far worse and more prolonged than any physical torture imaginable. The red-hot iron ball would cause terrible pain but only for a short time before death released one from it. But the karma of eating offerings unworthily while wearing robes fraudulently would result in eons of torment in hell. The immoral monk consuming alms food was essentially eating poison that would destroy him far more completely than any physical substance could. This teaching had a profound effect on those listening. Monks who had been lax in their practice became frightened and resolved to maintain their precepts carefully. Those who had been corrupt faced a choice: either genuinely reform their conduct or disrobe and return to lay life rather than continue accumulating such terrible karma.

verses.pali:
Cattāri ṭhānāni naro pamatto, āpajjati paradārūpasevī;
Apuññalābhaṁ na nikāmaseyyaṁ, nindaṁ tatīyaṁ nirayaṁ catutthaṁ.
verses.translation: Four misfortunes befall the heedless person who commits adultery: acquisition of demerit, disturbed sleep, blame as the third, and hell as the fourth.
verses.commentary: This verse specifically addresses adultery (paradāra-upasevī - going to another's spouse) and lists four progressive consequences that befall the heedless person (pamatta) who commits this transgression. First is 'apuññalābha' - acquisition of demerit or negative karma. Second is 'na nikāmaseyyaṁ' - inability to sleep peacefully due to anxiety and guilt. Third is 'nindā' - blame, criticism, and social disgrace. Fourth is 'niraya' - rebirth in hell. The verse shows how a single act of sexual misconduct creates both immediate and long-term suffering.

story.title: The Story of the Adulterous Man
story.content: In Sāvatthī, there lived a wealthy man who was married with a family. Despite having a devoted wife, he became infatuated with his neighbor's wife. Being heedless and giving in to his desires, he began having an illicit affair with this married woman. He thought himself clever, believing his secret meetings were undiscovered. However, the consequences described by the Buddha began manifesting immediately. First, he acquired tremendous demerit - the negative karma from breaking his marriage vows, violating another man's trust, and engaging in sexual misconduct began accumulating from the moment the affair started. This invisible karmic burden would follow him through lives. Second, he found he could no longer sleep peacefully. Anxiety plagued him constantly - fear of discovery, guilt about his deception, worry about complications. He would lie awake reviewing his lies and planning cover stories. Even when exhausted, his sleep was disturbed by nightmares and restlessness. Third, the affair was inevitably discovered, as such things usually are. The woman's husband learned of it, and soon the entire community knew. The adulterer faced devastating social blame and disgrace. His reputation was destroyed, his family shamed, his business relationships damaged. People who once respected him now scorned him. His own wife and children suffered humiliation. Fourth and most serious, when he died some years later (his health had deteriorated from the stress and guilt), the heavy negative karma from his adultery combined with other misdeeds led to his rebirth in a hell realm. There he experienced suffering far worse than any earthly consequence - prolonged torment as the result of his sexual misconduct and the betrayal of trust. When the Buddha heard this story, he spoke this verse to warn others of the four-fold consequences of adultery: immediate karmic burden, loss of peace even in this life, social disgrace and suffering, and ultimately rebirth in hellish states where the consequences are experienced in their full intensity.

verses.pali:
Apuññalābho ca gatī ca pāpikā, bhītassa bhītāya ratī ca thokikā;
Rājā ca daṇḍaṁ garukaṁ paṇeti, tasmā naro paradāraṁ na seve.
verses.translation: There is acquisition of demerit and an unhappy destination. The guilty man and the frightened woman have brief pleasure. The king imposes severe punishment. Therefore, let no man commit adultery.
verses.commentary: This verse continues the warning about adultery, adding more consequences. Beyond the four mentioned in the previous verse, it emphasizes: the unhappy rebirth destination (gatī pāpikā), the fact that the pleasure is minimal and fleeting (ratī thokikā) given the fear and guilt both parties experience (bhītassa bhītāya - frightened man and frightened woman), and the severe legal punishment (daṇḍaṁ garukaṁ) imposed by the king. The conclusion is direct: 'tasmā naro paradāraṁ na seve' - therefore, let no man go to another's spouse.

story.title: Continuation of the Adulterous Man's Story
story.content: The consequences for the adulterous man and his paramour were even more extensive than initially described. The Buddha elaborated on the full scope of suffering that resulted from their misconduct. Their negative karma (apuññalābha) not only accumulated but intensified because the affair continued over time. Each meeting added to their karmic burden. The destination (gati) awaiting them after death was decidedly evil - not just hell, but particularly painful regions of hell reserved for those who violated sacred trusts and marriage bonds. During the affair itself, the pleasure they sought was actually minimal and constantly tainted by fear. Both lived in anxiety - he feared discovery by his wife and her husband, while she feared her husband's anger and social exposure. They couldn't meet openly, had to lie constantly, and were always looking over their shoulders. Their few moments of illicit pleasure were overwhelmed by hours of guilt, anxiety, and fear. When finally discovered, the legal consequences proved severe. In that kingdom, the king took adultery seriously as a breach of social order and trust. The man was brought before the royal court, publicly tried, and subjected to heavy punishment - significant fines, public humiliation, and corporal punishment. His property was partially confiscated, his social status destroyed. The suffering in this life - social disgrace, family breakdown, anxiety, fear, guilt, legal punishment, and financial loss - was terrible enough. But all this was merely the prelude to the karmic consequences in future lives. When both died, their heavy burden of negative karma from sexual misconduct, lying, betrayal, and the suffering they had caused to innocent family members dragged them to painful rebirths. The Buddha taught this detailed account to emphasize his conclusion: No matter how strong the temptation, no matter how attractive the potential pleasure might seem, the consequences of adultery are so devastating and multi-layered that no rational person should ever engage in it.

verses.pali:
Kuso yathā duggahīto, hatthamevānukantati;
Sāmaññaṁ dupparāmaṭṭhaṁ, nirayāyūpakaḍḍhati.
verses.translation: Just as kusa grass, wrongly grasped, cuts the hand, so the monastic life wrongly practiced drags one to hell.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the simile of kusa grass, which has sharp edges. When grasped properly, it can be handled safely, but when grasped carelessly or wrongly (duggahīta), it cuts the hand. Similarly, the monastic life (sāmaññaṁ) when practiced carelessly or improperly (dupparāmaṭṭhaṁ) - without proper virtue, discipline, and sincerity - drags one to hell (nirayāya upakaḍḍhati) rather than to liberation. The verse warns that the religious life itself can be dangerous when not practiced correctly.

story.title: The Story of the Obstinate Monk
story.content: In Jetavana monastery, there lived two monks with contrasting attitudes toward monastic discipline. One day, the first monk accidentally cut some grass while walking, which is a minor offense under the Vinaya rules. He felt genuine remorse for this unwitting transgression and confided his concern to the second monk, seeking advice. However, the second monk was reckless and obstinate by nature. He dismissed the first monk's concern, saying: 'Cutting grass is such a trivial offense. Don't worry about it. Just confess it to another monk and you're automatically cleared. These minor rules aren't important anyway.' But his dismissive attitude didn't stop there. This obstinate monk habitually treated many precepts lightly. He would commit small offenses regularly, thinking them insignificant. He cut grass carelessly, handled vegetation roughly, ate at improper times, and violated numerous minor training rules. When others corrected him, he would argue that these were 'just small things' and 'not worth worrying about.' His entire approach to monastic life was slack and careless. Other monks became concerned about his attitude and reported the matter to the Buddha. The Buddha summoned the obstinate monk and spoke this verse. He explained: 'Kusa grass, when grasped properly and carefully, can be held safely. But when grasped carelessly or wrongly, its sharp edges cut the hand that holds it. Similarly, the monastic life - the life of a renunciant seeking liberation - can lead to the highest goal when practiced properly with care, discipline, and sincerity. But when practiced carelessly, treating precepts lightly, accumulating small violations, and maintaining a generally slack attitude, this same monastic life becomes dangerous. Instead of leading upward to liberation, it drags you downward to hell.' The Buddha continued: 'You think these minor rules don't matter, but you are fundamentally misunderstanding the nature of spiritual training. Each precept exists for a reason - to train mindfulness, to develop respect, to cultivate care in all actions. When you treat them carelessly, you're not just breaking rules; you're developing a mind that is careless, unmindful, and disrespectful. This mental habit will extend to major precepts as well. Moreover, by living as a monk while violating even minor rules, you consume offerings given in faith to the Sangha without fulfilling your side of that sacred exchange. This creates negative karma.' The obstinate monk, hearing this powerful teaching and recognizing the truth in the kusa grass simile, finally understood the danger of his careless approach. He realized he had been grasping his monastic life wrongly, and it was indeed cutting him spiritually. He reformed completely, becoming meticulous in his practice and eventually attaining Arahantship.

verses.pali:
Yaṁ kiñci sithilaṁ kammaṁ, saṅkiliṭṭhañca yaṁ vataṁ;
Saṅkassaraṁ brahmacariyaṁ, na taṁ hoti mahapphalaṁ.
verses.translation: Any lax action, any corrupt practice, any doubtful conduct of the holy life - none of these is of much benefit.
verses.commentary: This verse continues the warning about careless religious practice. 'Sithilaṁ kammaṁ' refers to lax or slack actions performed without proper care or energy. 'Saṅkiliṭṭhaṁ vataṁ' means corrupt or defiled practices - observances performed with wrong motivation or improperly. 'Saṅkassaraṁ brahmacariyaṁ' refers to doubtful or questionable holy life - conduct that raises suspicions or concerns. None of these approaches brings great benefit (mahapphala). The verse emphasizes that half-hearted or improper practice is essentially worthless.

story.title: Continuation of the Obstinate Monk
story.content: After speaking the previous verse about kusa grass, the Buddha continued teaching the obstinate monk, addressing his specific patterns of careless practice. The Buddha explained: 'Your entire approach to monastic life has been characterized by slackness, corruption, and doubtfulness. Let me show you what this means.' The Buddha pointed out examples from the monk's own behavior: 'When you perform your duties - cleaning the monastery, preparing for alms-round, or attending to your meditation practice - you do them in a sithila way, a lax and careless manner. You rush through cleaning without doing it properly. You prepare carelessly for alms-round, your robes poorly arranged. Your meditation sessions are perfunctory - you sit for the minimum time required, your mind wandering, making no real effort to develop concentration or insight. All your actions are slack.' 'Your vata - your practices and observances - are saṅkiliṭṭha, corrupted and defiled. You observe the forms externally while violating their spirit. You attend communal recitations but gossip during them. You participate in ceremonies but with irreverent attitudes. Your observances are polluted by wrong intentions and careless execution.' 'Your overall brahmacariya - your holy life - has become saṅkassara, doubtful and questionable. Other monks wonder about your sincerity. Lay supporters question whether you're a genuine practitioner. Your conduct raises suspicions rather than inspiring confidence. When people see you, they don't think here is a dedicated monk but rather is this person really serious about practice? The Buddha concluded: 'None of this slack, corrupt, questionable practice brings any significant benefit. You're wasting your life in robes. The monastic life is meant to be practiced with diligence, purity, and clarity of purpose. Half-measures and careless approaches produce no fruit. You must either practice properly with full commitment, or you should honestly disrobe rather than continuing this charade that benefits no one and creates negative karma for yourself.' This detailed critique had a profound impact on the obstinate monk, who finally recognized how his entire approach had been wrong.

verses.pali:
Kayirā ce kayirāthenaṁ, daḷhamenaṁ parakkame;
Sithilo hi paribbājo, bhiyyo ākirate rajaṁ.
verses.translation: If anything is to be done, let it be done with vigor; pursue it with firmness. For the lax renunciate scatters much dust of defilements.
verses.commentary: This verse provides the positive instruction following the warnings. 'Kayirā ce' means 'if something is to be done' - if one undertakes the religious life. 'Kayirāthenaṁ' urges doing it with vigor and energy. 'Daḷhamenaṁ parakkame' means pursue it firmly and energetically. 'Sithilo paribbājo' (the lax renunciate) scatters much dust (rajo) - a metaphor for defilements. The image suggests that careless practice not only fails to remove defilements but actually stirs them up and spreads them, like walking carelessly stirs up dust.

story.title: The Final Teaching to the Obstinate Monk
story.content: Having warned the obstinate monk about the dangers of careless practice through the previous two verses, the Buddha now provided clear positive instruction with this third verse. The Buddha told him: 'If you have decided to live the monastic life - if you are going to do this thing - then do it properly, with full vigor and commitment. Don't half-heartedly dabble in spiritual practice. Pursue it with firmness, energy, and complete dedication. Give it everything you have.' The Buddha elaborated: 'When you undertake any practice or duty, approach it with full energy. When you meditate, meditate with complete focus and determination, not in a lazy, perfunctory way. When you study the teachings, study with real attention and effort to understand deeply. When you maintain precepts, do so with careful mindfulness and respect for each rule, not carelessly. When you serve the community, serve wholeheartedly. Whatever you do as a monk, do it vigorously and firmly.' The Buddha then explained the metaphor: 'A lax renunciate - one who practices carelessly and without real commitment - is like someone walking carelessly through a dusty area. Instead of treading carefully to minimize stirring up dust, their careless movements kick up clouds of dust that spread everywhere, covering everything. Similarly, your careless practice doesn't reduce your defilements; it actually stirs them up and spreads them further. Your slack attitude cultivates more unmindfulness, more disrespect, more carelessness. Your defilements multiply rather than decrease. But if you practice with vigor, firmness, and genuine dedication, you will progressively eliminate defilements rather than multiplying them.' At the conclusion of this three-verse teaching, the obstinate monk experienced a profound transformation. He realized how wrong his entire approach had been. He saw clearly that his careless, dismissive attitude had been like wrongly grasping kusa grass - cutting himself spiritually. His slack practices had produced no benefit and had actually increased his defilements like scattered dust. From that moment, he completely reformed his conduct, practicing with utmost diligence, energy, and care. Through vigorous and firm practice of Insight Meditation, he eventually attained Arahantship, fulfilling the potential of the monastic life properly grasped.

verses.pali:
Akataṁ dukkaṭaṁ seyyo, pacchā tapati dukkaṭaṁ;
Katañca sukataṁ seyyo, yaṁ katvā nānutappati.
verses.translation: Better left undone is a bad deed, for it torments one later. Better done is a good deed, which having done, one does not regret.
verses.commentary: This verse presents a simple but profound principle about action and regret. 'Akataṁ dukkaṭaṁ' - an evil deed not done - is better (seyyo) because a 'dukkaṭaṁ' (evil deed) torments (tapati) one afterwards (pacchā). The word 'tapati' means burns or torments, suggesting both guilt in this life and karmic burning in future lives. Conversely, 'sukataṁ' - a good deed done - is better because one does not regret (nānutappati) having done it. The verse teaches that we should consider future consequences before acting.

story.title: The Story of the Jealous Woman
story.content: In Sāvatthī, there lived a woman who was consumed by jealousy toward her husband's second wife. Her jealousy festered over time, growing into hatred. One day, overwhelmed by rage and jealousy, she conceived a terrible plan to harm her rival. She waited until her co-wife was alone with her baby, then in a moment of blind fury, she threw the infant into a pot of boiling water, killing the child instantly. The mother's anguished screams brought everyone running. The truth quickly emerged, and the jealous woman was identified as the murderer. She was arrested and faced execution for her crime. But the torment began even before her legal punishment. Immediately after committing the deed, she was struck by overwhelming horror and remorse. The image of what she had done haunted her every moment. She couldn't eat or sleep, tormented by guilt and the memory of the innocent baby's death. The mother's grief-stricken face appeared before her constantly. She realized with crushing clarity that her jealous rage had led her to commit an unspeakable evil - murdering an innocent child. No matter how intense her jealousy had been, nothing could justify such an action. Her momentary rage had resulted in permanent, irreversible consequences. As she awaited execution, suffering from unbearable remorse and anticipating both death and the hellish rebirth that would follow due to her heinous deed, she desperately wished she had never committed this act. If only she had controlled her jealousy! If only she had left the evil deed undone! But it was too late - the deed was done, and now she would suffer its consequences. When the Buddha heard this story, he spoke this verse teaching: 'Better left undone is an evil deed, for it torments one afterwards. Better done is a good deed, which having done, one does not regret.' The Buddha explained that before acting on any impulse - especially anger, jealousy, or hatred - one should pause and consider the consequences. An evil deed, once committed, cannot be undone. It will torment the doer through guilt in this life and through karmic consequences in future lives. Far better to leave such deeds undone, no matter how strong the impulse. In contrast, good deeds - acts of kindness, generosity, patience, and compassion - never lead to regret. No one ever wishes they hadn't been kind or patient. Good deeds bring peace and happiness both immediately and in the long term.

verses.translation: As a border town is guarded both within and without, so guard yourself. Let not the moment pass you by. Those who let the moment pass grieve when they are consigned to hell.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the simile of a border city (paccanta-nagara) that must be well-guarded both inside and outside against enemy attack. Similarly, one should guard oneself (attānaṁ gopetha) - meaning guard one's virtue, mindfulness, and spiritual practice. 'Khaṇo mā upaccagā' warns not to let the opportune moment pass - the moment for practice, for developing virtue, for purifying the mind. Those who waste their opportunities (khaṇātītā) grieve when they end up in hell (nirayamhi samappitā). The verse emphasizes vigilance and the urgency of spiritual practice.

story.title: The Story of Many Monks
story.content: A large group of monks lived together in a monastery in a comfortable setting. They had reliable supporters, received ample food, enjoyed pleasant dwellings, and lived in a peaceful environment conducive to practice. They had everything necessary for spiritual development - a qualified teacher, good companions, sufficient time for meditation, access to teachings, and freedom from major worldly concerns. Despite these ideal conditions, many of these monks fell into complacency. They thought to themselves: 'We're still young and healthy. We have plenty of time for serious practice. Right now, we'll just maintain our basic duties and enjoy the peaceful monastic life. Later - maybe in a few years, or when we're older - we'll really buckle down and practice intensively. There's no rush.' So they went through the motions of monastic life but without genuine urgency or dedication. They attended ceremonies out of obligation but didn't practice sincerely. They meditated for short periods to fulfill minimum requirements but made no real effort toward concentration or insight. They studied teachings casually but didn't apply them deeply. Year after year passed this way, with each monk thinking 'I'll practice seriously later' while letting precious time and opportunity slip away. Then circumstances changed. The monastery's main benefactor died, and support decreased. Political instability arose in the region, making conditions less secure. Some monks fell ill. Others grew old, their bodies no longer able to sustain intensive practice. The ideal conditions they had taken for granted disappeared. Now, when they finally wanted to practice seriously, they found it much more difficult or even impossible. Some monks, now aged and ill, realized with deep regret that they had wasted their precious opportunity. When healthy and young with ideal conditions, they had procrastinated. Now, when they finally wanted to practice, they lacked the physical and mental capacity. Several died without having made significant progress, facing uncertain rebirths after having squandered the precious opportunity of human life in a monastery with a living Buddha teaching. When the Buddha learned about this situation, he called the monks together and spoke this verse. He explained: 'A border city - a frontier town near enemy territory - must be constantly vigilant, well-guarded both inside and outside, because attack can come at any moment. If the guards become complacent, thinking  we're safe, we can relax,the enemy will breach the defenses and destroy the city. Similarly, you must guard yourselves constantly - guard your virtue, guard your mindfulness, guard your practice. Internal enemies (defilements) and external challenges can strike at any time.' The Buddha continued: 'Do not let the opportune moment pass you by. Right now, you have this precious human life. Right now, you have met the Dhamma. Right now, you have the capacity to practice. Right now, conditions are relatively favorable. This moment - this very moment - is the time to practice. Don't postpone, thinking later or tomorrow or when I'm older. That opportune moment may never come again. Life is uncertain. Death can come at any moment. Conditions change. If you let these precious moments pass unused, you will grieve bitterly later, especially if you find yourselves reborn in hell because you wasted your opportunities and accumulated insufficient merit or wisdom.'

verses.pali:
Alajjitāye lajjanti, lajjitāye na lajjare;
Micchādiṭṭhisamādānā, sattā gacchanti duggatiṁ.
verses.translation: They are ashamed of what is not shameful and are not ashamed of what is shameful. Such beings who embrace wrong views go to woeful states.
verses.commentary: This verse describes moral confusion - being ashamed of what should not cause shame (alajjitāye lajjanti) and not ashamed of what should cause shame (lajjitāye na lajjare). Examples include: feeling ashamed of virtue, generosity, or spiritual practice while feeling no shame about evil deeds. 'Micchādiṭṭhi' (wrong view) is the root cause - when one's understanding of right and wrong is inverted, one's sense of shame becomes similarly inverted. Such beings (sattā) with wrong views go to woeful destinations (duggatiṁ) - hell realms and other unfortunate rebirths.

story.title: The Story of the Nigaṇṭhas (Jain Ascetics)
story.content: During the Buddha's time, there was a group of Jain ascetics (Nigaṇṭhas) who followed extremely austere practices based on their teacher's doctrines. Their belief system included the idea that the body was inherently evil and that severe mortification would burn away bad karma. Following these beliefs, they engaged in practices that shocked ordinary people and even disturbed the Buddha. These ascetics would go completely naked in public, considering clothing shameful because it represented attachment to comfort and modesty. When people - including women and children - saw them naked in towns and villages, the ascetics felt no shame whatsoever. Instead, they were proud, believing their nakedness demonstrated their spiritual advancement and freedom from worldly conventions. Conversely, these same ascetics felt ashamed of ordinary wholesome behaviors. When offered comfortable shelter during harsh weather, they refused it with contempt, feeling it would be shameful to accept such 'luxury.' When given good food by compassionate donors, they felt ashamed to eat it properly, believing simple living required them to eat in degrading ways or fast excessively. When suggested they should practice loving-kindness or help suffering beings, they dismissed such advice as shameful attachment to worldly concerns. Their entire value system was inverted. They felt pride in what should cause shame (public nakedness, harsh self-mortification, rejecting kindness) and shame in what should be sources of joy (accepting proper shelter, eating adequate food, practicing compassion). This moral confusion stemmed from their wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) - their fundamentally mistaken understanding about the nature of spiritual practice. They believed the body itself was evil rather than understanding that attachment and craving are the problems. They thought extreme mortification purified karma rather than understanding that mental purification through ethical conduct, concentration, and wisdom is the true path. They valued external austerity over internal transformation. When monks reported these Nigaṇṭhas' practices to the Buddha, he spoke this verse, explaining that beings who are ashamed of what is not shameful (like accepting proper requisites, showing modesty, practicing kindness) while feeling no shame about what truly is shameful (like harsh wrong practices, displaying improper behavior publicly, rejecting compassion) are following wrong views. Such wrong understanding leads them to woeful rebirths despite their sincere efforts, because they are pursuing a fundamentally mistaken path. The Buddha taught that true spiritual practice requires right view as its foundation - correct understanding of what is wholesome and unwholesome, what leads to liberation and what leads to suffering.

verses.pali:
Abhaye bhayadassino, bhaye cābhayadassino;
Micchādiṭṭhisamādānā, sattā gacchanti duggatiṁ.
verses.translation: Those who see danger in what is not dangerous and see no danger in what is dangerous - such beings who embrace wrong views go to woeful states.
verses.commentary: This verse parallels the previous one but focuses on perception of danger rather than shame. 'Abhaye bhayadassino' - seeing danger in what is not dangerous - includes fearing what is actually beneficial or harmless. 'Bhaye abhaye-dassino' - seeing no danger in what is dangerous - means failing to recognize true spiritual dangers. Again, wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) is the root cause of this misperception, leading to woeful rebirths (duggatiṁ). When one's understanding of danger is inverted, one avoids what would help and embraces what will harm.

story.title: The Story of Confused Practitioners
story.content: In the Buddha's time, various religious groups held different views about what constituted spiritual danger. Some, like the Nigaṇṭhas mentioned in the previous verse, saw danger in things that were actually harmless or even beneficial, while failing to see danger in genuinely harmful practices. For example, certain ascetics believed that accepting comfortable shelter was spiritually dangerous, fearing it would create attachment and lead to spiritual downfall. They saw terrible danger in something as simple as sleeping in a proper dwelling rather than exposed to weather. Yet these same practitioners saw no danger whatsoever in extreme self-mortification practices that severely harmed their health - practices like prolonged fasting to the point of starvation, remaining in painful postures until their bodies were damaged, or deliberately exposing themselves to extreme heat or cold. They considered these painful practices completely safe spiritually, even virtuous. Some religious teachers taught their followers that practicing loving-kindness toward all beings was dangerous because it created emotional attachments. They saw compassion and kindness as spiritual threats to be avoided. Yet they saw no danger in cultivating harsh, judgmental attitudes toward others - attitudes that actually hardened their hearts and increased ill-will. Certain groups believed that studying scriptures and learning was dangerous, fearing it would inflate pride and create attachment to knowledge. They saw terrible danger in education and intellectual understanding. Yet they saw no danger in remaining ignorant about the actual teachings of liberation - ignorance that would keep them trapped in wrong understanding indefinitely. Others feared that associating with wise teachers and noble companions was dangerous, believing it created dependency and hindered self-reliance. They saw grave danger in spiritual friendship. Yet they saw no danger in isolating themselves completely or associating with people who confirmed their wrong views - conditions that perpetuated delusion. When the Buddha observed these various forms of mistaken perception, he taught this verse. He explained: 'Those with wrong view see the world backwards. What is actually helpful appears dangerous to them; what is actually dangerous appears safe or even beneficial. This inverted perception stems from wrong understanding about the path to liberation.' The Buddha clarified what constitutes real danger: 'True spiritual danger lies in unwholesome states of mind - greed, hatred, and delusion. True danger lies in actions that harm oneself and others. True danger lies in wrong view itself, which misguides one's entire life. There is genuine danger in carelessness, in delaying practice, in breaking precepts, in harmful speech and actions.' He also explained what is not dangerous: 'There is no danger in accepting proper requisites with right attitude. There is no danger in studying true teachings. There is no danger in associating with wise teachers and noble friends. There is no danger in practicing loving-kindness and compassion. There is no danger in developing wisdom and understanding. These things are not threats but supports for liberation.'

verses.pali:
Avajje vajjamatino, vajje cāvajjadassino;
Micchādiṭṭhisamādānā, sattā gacchanti duggatiṁ.
verses.translation: Those who see fault in what is faultless and see no fault in what is faulty - such beings who embrace wrong views go to woeful states.
verses.commentary: This verse continues the pattern of describing inverted perception caused by wrong view. 'Avajje vajjamatino' - considering fault in what is faultless - means criticizing or rejecting what is actually wholesome and beneficial. 'Vajje avajja-dassino' - seeing no fault in what is faulty - means accepting or defending what is actually harmful and wrong. Like the previous verses, this emphasizes that wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) leads beings to woeful rebirths (duggatiṁ) because it causes them to reject the good and embrace the harmful.

story.title: The Story of Critics of the Dhamma
story.content: During the Buddha's ministry, there were individuals and groups who, due to wrong understanding, criticized wholesome practices while defending unwholesome ones. Their value system was inverted, causing them to reject the very teachings that could liberate them. Some brahmins found fault with the Buddha's teaching of equality, considering it a flaw that he accepted students from all castes including outcastes. They criticized as faulty the idea that one's spiritual capacity is determined by conduct rather than birth, believing this undermined proper social order. Yet these same critics saw no fault in the caste system's rigidity and cruelty, defending as faultless practices that caused immense suffering to millions. Certain ascetics found fault with the Buddha's Middle Way approach, criticizing his teaching to avoid extremes of indulgence and mortification. They considered it faulty and weak to accept proper food, clothing, and shelter. They found fault with the Buddha's monks for not practicing harsh austerities. Yet these critics saw no fault in extreme self-torture that damaged both body and mind - practices the Buddha recognized as harmful and futile. They defended as faultless the very practices that hindered rather than helped spiritual development. Some teachers found fault with the Buddha's emphasis on ethical conduct as the foundation of practice. They criticized the precepts and moral guidelines as faulty, considering them unnecessary restrictions that interfered with 'higher' spiritual pursuits. Yet they saw no fault in their followers committing various forms of misconduct, defending such behavior as irrelevant to spiritual attainment. They failed to recognize that ethical conduct is essential for mental purification. Various critics found fault with the Buddha's analytical approach and detailed teachings, complaining that his systematic explanation of the path was unnecessarily complex and faulty. They preferred simple, vague teachings. Yet they saw no fault in their own confused and incomplete understanding that left practitioners without clear guidance. They defended as faultless teachings that were actually ambiguous and misleading. Some found fault with the Buddha's rejection of various common religious practices - ritual sacrifices, fire worship, extreme asceticism, caste discrimination. They criticized these rejections as faults in his teaching, believing he was improperly discarding valuable traditions. Yet they saw no fault in these practices themselves, defending as faultless rituals and beliefs that perpetuated suffering and delusion. When the Buddha became aware of these various criticisms and inverted judgments, he taught this verse. He explained: 'Those with wrong view see faults where there are none and see no faults where faults actually exist. Their fundamental misunderstanding about the nature of reality and the path to liberation causes them to evaluate everything backwards. What is actually wholesome and beneficial appears faulty to them; what is actually harmful and wrong appears faultless.' The Buddha emphasized the importance of right view as the foundation: 'Only when understanding is correct can one properly discern what is truly faulty and what is truly faultless. Right view allows one to recognize that the path of virtue, wisdom, and mental purification is faultless, while the path of misconduct, ignorance, and mental defilement is faulty. Without this correct foundation, one rejects help and embraces harm, leading inevitably to woeful rebirths.'

verses.pali:
Vajjañca vajjato ñatvā, avajjañca avajjato;
Sammādiṭṭhisamādānā, sattā gacchanti suggatiṁ.
verses.translation: But knowing the faulty as faulty and the faultless as faultless - such beings who embrace right views go to happy states.
verses.commentary: This final verse of the chapter provides the positive conclusion. Those who correctly understand 'vajjañca vajjato' (the faulty as faulty) and 'avajjañca avajjato' (the faultless as faultless) embrace right view (sammādiṭṭhi) and therefore go to happy destinations (suggatiṁ) - fortunate rebirths and ultimately Nibbāna. Right view is the foundation of all progress - when understanding is correct, all else follows naturally. This verse concludes the chapter by emphasizing that right view leads to happiness while wrong view leads to suffering.

story.title: The Story of Those Who Understood Correctly
story.content: In contrast to the confused practitioners and critics described in the previous verses, many people during the Buddha's time developed right view and thereby correctly distinguished between what was faulty and faultless. These individuals heard the Buddha's teachings and understood them correctly, recognizing which practices and views were wholesome and which were harmful. When the Buddha taught the Four Noble Truths, they understood: suffering is truly suffering (faulty condition); craving is truly the cause of suffering (faulty); cessation of suffering is truly possible (faultless goal); and the Noble Eightfold Path is truly the way (faultless method). They didn't confuse cause and effect or reject these truths. When the Buddha taught ethical conduct, they recognized that killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and intoxication are truly faulty - harmful actions that create suffering for oneself and others. They saw that abstaining from these actions and practicing their opposites - protecting life, generosity, faithfulness, truthfulness, and mindfulness - are faultless and beneficial. When the Buddha taught meditation and mental development, they correctly understood that cultivating loving-kindness, compassion, concentration, and wisdom is faultless - these practices genuinely purify the mind and lead toward liberation. They saw that harsh, judgmental, scattered, and ignorant mental states are faulty - these actually obstruct progress. When the Buddha explained the Middle Way, avoiding extremes of indulgence and self-mortification, they recognized this balanced approach as faultless - it actually works. They saw that extreme indulgence (faultily seeking happiness through sensual pleasure) and extreme asceticism (faultily seeking purification through bodily torture) were both mistaken approaches. These practitioners with right view made steady progress. They practiced the precepts, recognizing them as faultless guidelines. They studied the teachings, understanding them as faultless wisdom. They developed meditation, recognizing it as a faultless method. They associated with the wise, seeing such companionship as faultless support. Through maintaining right view and correctly discerning faulty from faultless, many attained Stream-entry, Some-returning, Non-returning, or even Arahantship - happy states beyond all suffering. Others, though not yet enlightened, generated great merit through their wholesome actions based on right understanding, ensuring favorable rebirths where they could continue their practice. When the Buddha concluded his teaching on wrong view and right view with this verse, he wanted to make absolutely clear: The foundation of spiritual practice is correct understanding - right view. With right view, one naturally recognizes what leads to suffering (the faulty) and what leads to happiness and liberation (the faultless). This correct discernment guides all subsequent choices and actions, leading inevitably to happy destinations. Without right view, all one's efforts may be misdirected, like the confused practitioners who rejected what could help them and embraced what harmed them. Therefore, cultivating right view must be the first priority in spiritual practice.

chapters.summary: Using the elephant as a metaphor for strength and training, this chapter teaches about endurance, self-control, and the taming of one's mind and senses.

verses.pali: Ahaṁ nāgo'va saṅgāme, cāpāto patitaṁ saraṁ; Ativākyaṁ titikkhissaṁ, dussīlo hi bahujjano.
verses.translation: As an elephant in the battlefield withstands arrows shot from bows all around, even so shall I endure abuse. There are many, indeed, who lack virtue.
verses.commentary: The Buddha compares himself to a war elephant that endures arrows with patience and fortitude. In the same way, one should endure harsh words and abuse without retaliation. Many people lack moral discipline, so encountering criticism is inevitable. The wise person remains unmoved like the steadfast elephant.

story.title: The Story of Queen Māgaṇḍiyā
story.content: While residing at Ghosita Monastery in Kosambi, the Buddha faced orchestrated abuse from Queen Māgaṇḍiyā, who harbored deep resentment against him. She hired vagabonds and troublemakers to follow the Buddha and his monks through the streets, hurling insults: "You are a thief! A fool! An idiot! A camel! A donkey! Destined for hell!" The abuse continued relentlessly for seven days. Venerable Ānanda, unable to bear witnessing such disrespect toward his teacher, suggested they leave for another city. The Buddha gently refused, explaining that running away solves nothing. Instead, he taught the principle of endurance, comparing himself to a battle elephant that stands firm despite arrows raining from all directions. After seven days, the crowd grew weary and abandoned their campaign. The Buddha explained that patience and non-retaliation represent true strength. Like the elephant that does not flee despite pain, practitioners should remain steadfast when facing unjust criticism, recognizing that such behavior reflects the critic's defilements, not reality.

verses.pali: Dantaṁ nayanti samitiṁ, dantaṁ rājābhirūhati; Danto seṭṭho manussesu, yo'tivākyaṁ titikkhati.
verses.translation: A tamed elephant is led into a crowd, and the king mounts a tamed elephant. Best among men is the subdued one who endures abuse.
verses.commentary: Just as a well-trained elephant becomes valuable for royal service and public gatherings, a person who has tamed their mind becomes most excellent among humans. The ability to endure harsh speech without retaliation marks true self-mastery. Such restraint demonstrates inner strength far greater than any physical prowess.

story.title: The Story of the Tamed Elephant
story.content: Continuing his teaching on endurance, the Buddha elaborated on the value of self-discipline. In ancient India, elephants served crucial roles in warfare, ceremonies, and royal processions. However, only perfectly trained elephants could be trusted in crowds or bear the king's weight in battle. Wild, untamed elephants were useless despite their strength. The process of taming required patience, consistency, and wisdom from skilled trainers. Similarly, the Buddha explained, untamed humans—regardless of physical strength, wealth, or social position—remain unsuitable for the highest spiritual purposes. Those who react impulsively to criticism, harbor resentment, or retaliate against perceived insults demonstrate a lack of inner training. In contrast, individuals who have mastered their reactions, controlling anger and maintaining equanimity under provocation, become like royal elephants—dignified, reliable, and worthy of respect. The Buddha emphasized that such self-control requires daily practice, mindfulness, and determination. True nobility comes not from birth or power but from the patient cultivation of mental discipline and emotional restraint.

verses.pali: Varamassatarā dantā, ājānīyā ca Sindhavā; Kuñjarā ca mahānāgā, attadanto tato varaṁ.
verses.translation: Excellent are well-trained mules, thoroughbred Sindhu horses and noble tusker elephants. But better still is the man who has subdued himself.
verses.commentary: This verse compares various prized animals known for their training—mules for endurance, Sindhu horses for nobility, and great elephants for strength. Yet one who has tamed their own mind surpasses all these. Self-mastery represents the highest achievement because it leads to liberation from suffering.

story.title: The Story of the Royal Stables
story.content: The Buddha once visited the royal stables where King Pasenadi kept his prized animals. The finest mules carried heavy loads across mountains without complaint. Magnificent horses from the Sindhu region—bred for generations for courage and speed—stood ready for battle. Most impressive were the royal elephants, massive creatures trained for warfare and ceremony. The king proudly displayed these animals, explaining the years of careful training each required. The Buddha acknowledged their excellence but taught a profound lesson: despite their value, these animals could never achieve liberation from suffering. They might be trained to perform tasks, but they could not comprehend Dhamma or attain enlightenment. A human who trains their own mind, however, achieves something infinitely superior. Through meditation, ethical conduct, and wisdom, one transcends the cycle of rebirth entirely. The Buddha explained that while animal training focuses on external behavior, human self-training transforms consciousness itself. A person who has conquered greed, hatred, and delusion surpasses the worth of all treasured animals combined, for they have achieved the ultimate goal—freedom from suffering.

verses.pali: Na hi etehi yānehi, gaccheyya agataṁ disaṁ; Yathāttanā sudantena, danto dantena gacchati.
verses.translation: Not by these mounts, however, would one go to the Untrodden Land (Nibbāna), as one who is self-tamed goes by his own tamed and well-controlled mind.
verses.commentary: No external vehicle—however excellent—can carry one to Nibbāna, the uncharted territory beyond suffering. Only through self-discipline and mental purification can one reach that destination. The well-trained mind becomes its own vehicle to liberation, requiring no external aid.

story.title: The Story of the Elephant Trainer Monk
story.content: A bhikkhu who had formerly worked as an elephant trainer was watching trainers struggle with a particularly difficult elephant. Unable to resist, he whispered to another monk a specific technique that would work. The elephant trainer overheard, applied the suggestion, and successfully tamed the elephant. When the Buddha heard about this incident, he summoned the former trainer monk. The bhikkhu expected praise for his helpful knowledge, but the Buddha taught a different lesson entirely.
